before you even know what you're watching.

00:12:41.918 --> 00:12:45.934
Or you may be tempted to look at material
that you wouldn't look at in everyday life

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:49.078
or you wouldn't look at if you
were with other people at the time.

00:12:50.078 --> 00:12:52.974
And when the action is pre-recorded

00:12:52.998 --> 00:12:57.214
and takes place
in a distant time and space,

00:12:57.238 --> 00:13:01.214
watching seems like a passive activity.

00:13:01.238 --> 00:13:03.048
There's nothing I can do about it now.

00:13:03.078 --> 00:13:04.628
It's already happened.

00:13:05.118 --> 00:13:08.414
All these things make it easier
as an Internet user

00:13:08.438 --> 00:13:12.254
for us to give in to our sense
of curiosity about death,

00:13:12.278 --> 00:13:14.974
to push our personal boundaries,

00:13:14.998 --> 00:13:19.918
to test our sense of shock,
to explore our sense of shock.

00:13:21.318 --> 00:13:23.654
But we're not passive when we watch.

00:13:23.678 --> 00:13:28.174
On the contrary, we're fulfilling
the murderer's desire to be seen.

00:13:28.198 --> 00:13:32.654
When the victim of a decapitation
is bound and defenseless,

00:13:32.678 --> 00:13:37.158
he or she essentially becomes
a pawn in their killer's show.

00:13:38.478 --> 00:13:41.334
Unlike a trophy head
that's taken in battle,

00:13:41.358 --> 00:13:45.678
that represents the luck and skill
it takes to win a fight,

00:13:47.158 --> 00:13:49.294
when a beheading is staged,

00:13:49.318 --> 00:13:52.254
when it's essentially a piece of theater,

00:13:52.278 --> 00:13:57.758
the power comes from the reception
the killer receives as he performs.

00:13:58.838 --> 00:14:03.574
In other words, watching
is very much part of the event.

00:14:03.598 --> 00:14:07.134
The event no longer takes place
in a single location

00:14:07.158 --> 00:14:12.318
at a certain point in time as it used to
and as it may still appear to.

00:14:13.158 --> 00:14:17.094
Now the event is stretched out
in time and place,

00:14:17.118 --> 00:14:20.078
and everyone who watches plays their part.

00:14:21.478 --> 00:14:23.358
We should stop watching,

00:14:24.078 --> 00:14:25.638
but we know we won't.

00:14:26.398 --> 00:14:28.854
History tells us we won't,

00:14:28.878 --> 00:14:30.478
and the killers know it too.

00:14:31.198 --> 00:14:32.414
Thank you.

00:14:32.438 --> 00:14:36.934
(Applause)

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:39.854
Bruno Giussani: Thank you.
Let me get this back. Thank you.

00:14:39.878 --> 00:14:42.774
Let's move here. While they install
for the next performance,

00:14:42.798 --> 00:14:45.654
I want to ask you the question
that probably many here have,

00:14:45.678 --> 00:14:48.278
which is how did you
get interested in this topic?

00:14:50.318 --> 00:14:52.334
Frances Larson: I used to work at a museum

00:14:52.358 --> 00:14:54.294
called the Pitt Rivers Museum in Oxford,

00:14:54.318 --> 00:14:58.174
which was famous for its display
of shrunken heads from South America.

00:14:58.198 --> 00:15:02.134
People used to say, "Oh, the shrunken head
museum, the shrunken head museum!"

00:15:02.158 --> 00:15:05.774
And at the time,
I was working on the history

00:15:05.798 --> 00:15:07.814
of scientific collections of skulls.

00:15:07.838 --> 00:15:10.414
I was working on the cranial collections,

00:15:10.438 --> 00:15:12.254
and it just struck me as ironic

00:15:12.278 --> 00:15:17.054
that here were people coming to see
this gory, primitive, savage culture

00:15:17.078 --> 00:15:20.598
that they were almost
fantasizing about and creating

00:15:21.918 --> 00:15:24.299
without really understanding
what they were seeing,

00:15:24.323 --> 00:15:27.894
and all the while these vast --
I mean hundreds of thousands

00:15:27.918 --> 00:15:32.054
of skulls in our museums,
all across Europe and the States --

00:15:32.078 --> 00:15:37.334
were kind of upholding this Enlightenment
pursuit of scientific rationality.

00:15:37.358 --> 00:15:42.414
So I wanted to kind of twist it round
and say, "Let's look at us."

00:15:42.438 --> 00:15:45.334
We're looking through the glass case
at these shrunken heads.

00:15:45.358 --> 00:15:49.894
Let's look at our own history and our own
cultural fascination with these things.

00:15:49.918 --> 00:15:51.735
BG: Thank you for sharing that.

00:15:51.760 --> 00:15:52.934
FL: Thank you.

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:56.038
(Applause)

title: Why climate change is a threat to human rights
transcript: A question I'm often asked is, where did I get my passion for human rights and justice? It started early. I grew up in the west of Ireland, wedged between four brothers, two older than me and two younger than me. So of course I had to be interested in human rights, and equality and justice, and using my elbows!(Laughter)And those issues stayed with me and guided me, and in particular, when I was elected the first woman President of Ireland, from 1990 to 1997. I dedicated my presidency to having a space for those who felt marginalized on the island of Ireland, and bringing together communities from Northern Ireland with those from the Republic, trying to build peace. And I went as the first Irish president to the United Kingdom and met with Queen Elizabeth II, and also welcomed to my official residence — which we call "Áras an Uachtaráin," the house of the president — members of the royal family, including, notably, the Prince of Wales. And I was aware that at the time of my presidency, Ireland was a country beginning a rapid economic progress. We were a country that was benefiting from the solidarity of the European Union. Indeed, when Ireland first joined the European Union in 1973, there were parts of the country that were considered developing, including my own beloved native county, County Mayo. I led trade delegations here to the United States, to Japan, to India, to encourage investment, to help to create jobs, to build up our economy, to build up our health system, our education — our development.What I didn't have to do as president was buy land on mainland Europe, so that Irish citizens could go there because our island was going underwater. What I didn't have to think about, either as president or as a constitutional lawyer, was the implications for the sovereignty of the territory because of the impact of climate change. But that is what President Tong, of the Republic of Kiribati, has to wake up every morning thinking about. He has bought land in Fiji as an insurance policy, what he calls, "migration with dignity," because he knows that his people may have to leave their islands. As I listened to President Tong describing the situation, I really felt that this was a problem that no leader should have to face. And as I heard him speak about the pain of his problems, I thought about Eleanor Roosevelt. I thought about her and those who worked with her on the Commission on Human Rights, which she chaired in 1948, and drew up the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. For them, it would have been unimaginable that a whole country could go out of existence because of human-induced climate change.I came to climate change not as a scientist or an environmental lawyer, and I wasn't really impressed by the images of polar bears or melting glaciers. It was because of the impact on people, and the impact on their rights — their rights to food and safe water, health, education and shelter. And I say this with humility, because I came late to the issue of climate change. When I served as UN High Commissioner for Human Rights from 1997 to 2002, climate change wasn't at the front of my mind. I don't remember making a single speech on climate change. I knew that there was another part of the United Nations — the UN Convention on Climate Change — that was dealing with the issue of climate change. It was later when I started to work in African countries on issues of development and human rights. And I kept hearing this pervasive sentence: "Oh, but things are so much worse now, things are so much worse." And then I explored what was behind that; it was about changes in the climate — climate shocks, changes in the weather.I met Constance Okollet, who had formed a women's group in Eastern Uganda, and she told me that when she was growing up, she had a very normal life in her village and they didn't go hungry, they knew that the seasons would come as they were predicted to come, they knew when to sow and they knew when to harvest, and so they had enough food. But, in recent years, at the time of this conversation, they had nothing but long periods of drought, and then flash flooding, and then more drought. The school had been destroyed, livelihoods had been destroyed, their harvest had been destroyed. She forms this women's group to try to keep her community together. And this was a reality that really struck me, because of course, Constance Okollet wasn't responsible for the greenhouse gas emissions that were causing this problem.Indeed, I was very struck about the situation in Malawi in January of this year. There was an unprecedented flooding in the country, it covered about a third of the country, over 300 people were killed, and hundreds of thousands lost their livelihoods. And the average person in Malawi emits about 80 kg of CO2 a year. The average US citizen emits about 17.5 metric tons. So those who are suffering disproportionately don't drive cars, don't have electricity, don't consume very significantly, and yet they are feeling more and more the impacts of the changes in the climate, the changes that are preventing them from knowing how to grow food properly, and knowing how to look after their future. I think it was really the importance of the injustice that really struck me very forcibly.And I know that we're not able to address some of that injustice because we're not on course for a safe world. Governments around the world agreed at the conference in Copenhagen, and have repeated it at every conference on climate, that we have to stay below two degrees Celsius of warming above pre-Industrial standards. But we're on course for about four degrees. So we face an existential threat to the future of our planet. And that made me realize that climate change is the greatest threat to human rights in the 21st century.And that brought me then to climate justice. Climate justice responds to the moral argument — both sides of the moral argument — to address climate change. First of all, to be on the side of those who are suffering most and are most effected. And secondly, to make sure that they're not left behind again, when we start to move and start to address climate change with climate action, as we are doing.In our very unequal world today, it's very striking how many people are left behind. In our world of 7.2 billion people, about 3 billion are left behind. 1.3 billion don't have access to electricity, and they light their homes with kerosene and candles, both of which are dangerous. And in fact they spend a lot of their tiny income on that form of lighting. 2.6 billion people cook on open fires — on coal, wood and animal dung. And this causes about 4 million deaths a year from indoor smoke inhalation, and of course, most of those who die are women. So we have a very unequal world, and we need to change from "business as usual." And we shouldn't underestimate the scale and the transformative nature of the change which will be needed, because we have to go to zero carbon emissions by about 2050, if we're going to stay below two degrees Celsius of warming. And that means we have to leave about two-thirds of the known resources of fossil fuels in the ground.It's a very big change, and it means that obviously, industrialized countries must cut their emissions, must become much more energy-efficient, and must move as quickly as possible to renewable energy. For developing countries and emerging economies, the problem and the challenge is to grow without emissions, because they must develop; they have very poor populations. So they must develop without emissions, and that is a different kind of problem. Indeed, no country in the world has actually grown without emissions. All the countries have developed with fossil fuels, and then may be moving to renewable energy. So it is a very big challenge, and it requires the total support of the international community, with the necessary finance and technology, and systems and support, because no country can make itself safe from the dangers of climate change. This is an issue that requires complete human solidarity. Human solidarity, if you like, based on self-interest — because we are all in this together, and we have to work together to ensure that we reach zero carbon by 2050.The good news is that change is happening, and it's happening very fast. Here in California, there's a very ambitious emissions target to cut emissions. In Hawaii, they're passing legislation to have 100 percent renewable energy by 2045. And governments are very ambitious around the world. In Costa Rica, they have committed to being carbon-neutral by 2021. In Ethiopia, the commitment is to be carbon-neutral by 2027. Apple have pledged that their factories in China will use renewable energy. And there is a race on at the moment to convert electricity from tidal and wave power, in order that we can leave the coal in the ground. And that change is both welcome and is happening very rapidly. But it's still not enough, and the political will is still not enough.Let me come back to President Tong and his people in Kiribati. They actually could be able to live on their island and have a solution, but it would take a lot of political will. President Tong told me about his ambitious idea to either build up or even float the little islands where his people live. This, of course, is beyond the resources of Kiribati itself. It would require great solidarity and support from other countries, and it would require the kind of imaginative idea that we bring together when we want to have a space station in the air. But wouldn't it be wonderful to have this engineering wonder and to allow a people to remain in their sovereign territory, and be part of the community of nations? That is the kind of idea that we should be thinking about. Yes, the challenges of the transformation we need are big, but they can be solved. We are actually, as a people, very capable of coming together to solve problems.I was very conscious of this as I took part this year in commemoration of the 70th anniversary of the end of the Second World War in 1945. 1945 was an extraordinary year. It was a year when the world faced what must have seemed almost insoluble problems — the devastation of the world wars, particularly the Second World War; the fragile peace that had been brought about; the need for a whole economic regeneration. But the leaders of that time didn't flinch from this. They had the capacity, they had a sense of being driven by never again must the world have this kind of problem. And they had to build structures for peace and security. And what did we get? What did they achieve? The Charter of the United Nations, the Bretton Woods institutions, as they're called, The World Bank, and the International Monetary Fund. A Marshall Plan for Europe, a devastated Europe, to reconstruct it. And indeed a few years later, the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.2015 is a year that is similar in its importance to 1945, with similar challenges and similar potential. There will be two big summits this year: the first one, in September in New York, is the summit for the sustainable development goals. And then the summit in Paris in December, to give us a climate agreement. The sustainable development goals are intended to help countries to live sustainably, in tune with Mother Earth, not to take out of Mother Earth and destroy ecosystems, but rather, to live in harmony with Mother Earth, by living under sustainable development. And the sustainable development goals will come into operation for all countries on January 1, 2016. The climate agreement — a binding climate agreement — is needed because of the scientific evidence that we're on a trajectory for about a four-degree world and we have to change course to stay below two degrees. So we need to take steps that will be monitored and reviewed, so that we can keep increasing the ambition of how we cut emissions, and how we move more rapidly to renewable energy, so that we have a safe world.The reality is that this issue is much too important to be left to politicians and to the United Nations.(Laughter)It's an issue for all of us, and it's an issue where we need more and more momentum. Indeed, the face of the environmentalist has changed, because of the justice dimension. It's now an issue for faith-based organizations, under very good leadership from Pope Francis, and indeed, the Church of England, which is divesting from fossil fuels. It's an issue for the business community, and the good news is that the business community is changing very rapidly — except for the fossil fuel industries —(Laughter)Even they are beginning to slightly change their language — but only slightly. But business is not only moving rapidly to the benefits of renewable energy, but is urging politicians to give them more signals, so that they can move even more rapidly. It's an issue for the trade union movement. It's an issue for the women's movement. It's an issue for young people.I was very struck when I learned that Jibreel Khazan, one of the Greensboro Four who had taken part in the Woolworth sit-ins, said quite recently that climate change is the lunch counter moment for young people. So, lunch counter moment for young people of the 21st century — the sort of real human rights issue of the 21st century, because he said it is the greatest challenge to humanity and justice in our world.I recall very much the Climate March last September, and that was a huge momentum, not just in New York, but all around the world. and we have to build on that. I was marching with some of The Elders family, and I saw a placard a little bit away from me, but we were wedged so closely together — because after all, there were 400,000 people out in the streets of New York — so I couldn't quite get to that placard, I would have just liked to have been able to step behind it, because it said, "Angry Grannies!"(Laughter)That's what I felt. And I have five grandchildren now, I feel very happy as an Irish grandmother to have five grandchildren, and I think about their world, and what it will be like when they will share that world with about 9 billion other people in 2050. We know that inevitably it will be a climate-constrained world, because of the emissions we've already put up there, but it could be a world that is much more equal and much fairer, and much better for health, and better for jobs and better for energy security, than the world we have now, if we have switched sufficiently and early enough to renewable energy, and no one is left behind. No one is left behind.And just as we've been looking back this year — in 2015 to 1945, looking back 70 years — I would like to think that they will look back, that world will look back 35 years from 2050, 35 years to 2015, and that they will say, "Weren't they good to do what they did in 2015? We really appreciate that they took the decisions that made a difference, and that put the world on the right pathway, and we benefit now from that pathway," that they will feel that somehow we took our responsibilities, we did what was done in 1945 in similar terms, we didn't miss the opportunity, we lived up to our responsibilities. That's what this year is about.And somehow for me, it's captured in words of somebody that I admired very much. She was a mentor of mine, she was a friend, she died much too young, she was an extraordinary personality, a great champion of the environment: Wangari Maathai. Wangari said once, "In the course of history, there comes a time when humanity is called upon to shift to a new level of consciousness, to reach a higher moral ground." And that's what we have to do. We have to reach a new level of consciousness, a higher moral ground. And we have to do it this year in those two big summits. And that won't happen unless we have the momentum from people around the world who say: "We want action now, we want to change course, we want a safe world, a safe world for future generations, a safe world for our children and our grandchildren, and we're all in this together."Thank you.(Applause)

00:06:28.396 --> 00:06:30.562
over 300 people were killed,

00:06:30.586 --> 00:06:33.879
and hundreds of thousands
lost their livelihoods.

00:06:34.346 --> 00:06:37.442
And the average person in Malawi

00:06:37.466 --> 00:06:42.409
emits about 80 kg of CO2 a year.

00:06:43.124 --> 00:06:48.648
The average US citizen emits
about 17.5 metric tons.

00:06:49.084 --> 00:06:52.775
So those who are suffering
disproportionately

00:06:52.799 --> 00:06:59.640
don't drive cars, don't have electricity,
don't consume very significantly,

00:06:59.664 --> 00:07:02.822
and yet they are feeling more and more

00:07:02.846 --> 00:07:07.235
the impacts of the changes in the climate,

00:07:07.259 --> 00:07:11.528
the changes that are preventing them
from knowing how to grow food properly,

00:07:11.552 --> 00:07:15.171
and knowing how
to look after their future.

00:07:15.472 --> 00:07:22.472
I think it was really
the importance of the injustice

00:07:22.989 --> 00:07:25.995
that really struck me very forcibly.

00:07:26.019 --> 00:07:33.019
And I know that we're not able
to address some of that injustice

00:07:33.094 --> 00:07:36.561
because we're not on course
for a safe world.

00:07:36.585 --> 00:07:42.974
Governments around the world agreed
at the conference in Copenhagen,

00:07:42.998 --> 00:07:46.712
and have repeated it
at every conference on climate,

00:07:46.736 --> 00:07:50.196
that we have to stay
below two degrees Celsius

00:07:50.220 --> 00:07:53.607
of warming above pre-Industrial standards.

00:07:53.631 --> 00:07:56.543
But we're on course
for about four degrees.

00:07:56.567 --> 00:08:01.440
So we face an existential threat
to the future of our planet.

00:08:01.464 --> 00:08:03.084
And that made me realize

00:08:03.108 --> 00:08:09.191
that climate change is the greatest threat
to human rights in the 21st century.

00:08:09.524 --> 00:08:13.159
And that brought me then
to climate justice.

00:08:13.183 --> 00:08:17.342
Climate justice responds
to the moral argument --

00:08:17.366 --> 00:08:19.398
both sides of the moral argument --

00:08:19.422 --> 00:08:21.840
to address climate change.

00:08:21.864 --> 00:08:23.015
First of all,

00:08:23.039 --> 00:08:26.903
to be on the side of those who are
suffering most and are most effected.

00:08:27.252 --> 00:08:28.609
And secondly,

00:08:28.633 --> 00:08:33.634
to make sure that they're not left behind
again, when we start to move

00:08:33.658 --> 00:08:36.467
and start to address climate change
with climate action,

00:08:36.491 --> 00:08:38.013
as we are doing.

00:08:39.792 --> 00:08:42.586
In our very unequal world today,

00:08:42.610 --> 00:08:46.189
it's very striking how many
people are left behind.

00:08:46.887 --> 00:08:52.895
In our world of 7.2 billion people,
about 3 billion are left behind.

00:08:53.220 --> 00:08:57.633
1.3 billion don't have access
to electricity,

00:08:57.657 --> 00:09:01.161
and they light their homes
with kerosene and candles,

00:09:01.185 --> 00:09:02.860
both of which are dangerous.

00:09:02.884 --> 00:09:09.375
And in fact they spend a lot of their
tiny income on that form of lighting.

00:09:09.399 --> 00:09:13.252
2.6 billion people cook on open fires --

00:09:13.752 --> 00:09:17.261
on coal, wood and animal dung.

00:09:17.285 --> 00:09:21.959
And this causes
about 4 million deaths a year

00:09:21.983 --> 00:09:24.205
from indoor smoke inhalation,

00:09:24.229 --> 00:09:28.139
and of course, most of those
who die are women.

00:09:28.750 --> 00:09:32.591
So we have a very unequal world,

00:09:33.004 --> 00:09:39.059
and we need to change
from "business as usual."

00:09:39.083 --> 00:09:45.147
And we shouldn't underestimate
the scale and the transformative nature

00:09:45.171 --> 00:09:47.908
of the change which will be needed,

00:09:47.932 --> 00:09:54.521
because we have to go to zero
carbon emissions by about 2050,

00:09:54.545 --> 00:09:58.910
if we're going to stay below
two degrees Celsius of warming.

00:09:58.934 --> 00:10:03.934
And that means we have to leave
about two-thirds of the known resources

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:06.165
of fossil fuels in the ground.

00:10:06.522 --> 00:10:08.245
It's a very big change,

00:10:08.269 --> 00:10:10.801
and it means that obviously,

00:10:10.825 --> 00:10:13.467
industrialized countries
must cut their emissions,

00:10:13.491 --> 00:10:15.562
must become much more energy-efficient,

00:10:15.586 --> 00:10:19.522
and must move as quickly as possible
to renewable energy.

00:10:20.157 --> 00:10:24.537
For developing countries
and emerging economies,

00:10:24.561 --> 00:10:29.118
the problem and the challenge
is to grow without emissions,

00:10:29.142 --> 00:10:32.456
because they must develop;
they have very poor populations.

00:10:32.480 --> 00:10:38.240
So they must develop without emissions,
and that is a different kind of problem.

00:10:38.548 --> 00:10:43.563
Indeed, no country in the world
has actually grown without emissions.

00:10:44.090 --> 00:10:46.494
All the countries have developed
with fossil fuels,

00:10:46.518 --> 00:10:48.816
and then may be moving
to renewable energy.

00:10:48.840 --> 00:10:51.179
So it is a very big challenge,

00:10:51.203 --> 00:10:55.913
and it requires the total support
of the international community,

00:10:55.937 --> 00:11:00.873
with the necessary finance and technology,
and systems and support,

00:11:00.897 --> 00:11:07.659
because no country can make itself safe
from the dangers of climate change.

00:11:07.965 --> 00:11:12.613
This is an issue that requires
complete human solidarity.

00:11:13.264 --> 00:11:16.601
Human solidarity, if you like,
based on self-interest --

00:11:16.625 --> 00:11:18.905
because we are all in this together,

00:11:18.929 --> 00:11:20.324
and we have to work together

00:11:20.348 --> 00:11:25.738
to ensure that we reach
zero carbon by 2050.

00:11:26.633 --> 00:11:29.396
The good news is that change is happening,

00:11:29.420 --> 00:11:31.324
and it's happening very fast.

00:11:32.089 --> 00:11:33.363
Here in California,

00:11:33.387 --> 00:11:37.393
there's a very ambitious
emissions target to cut emissions.

00:11:37.924 --> 00:11:40.729
In Hawaii, they're passing legislation

00:11:40.753 --> 00:11:45.379
to have 100 percent
renewable energy by 2045.

00:11:45.689 --> 00:11:49.339
And governments are very ambitious
around the world.

00:11:49.689 --> 00:11:54.356
In Costa Rica, they have committed
to being carbon-neutral by 2021.

00:11:55.068 --> 00:12:01.136
In Ethiopia, the commitment
is to be carbon-neutral by 2027.

00:12:01.879 --> 00:12:08.094
Apple have pledged that their factories
in China will use renewable energy.

00:12:08.398 --> 00:12:11.251
And there is a race on at the moment

00:12:11.275 --> 00:12:15.212
to convert electricity
from tidal and wave power,

00:12:15.236 --> 00:12:19.455
in order that we can leave
the coal in the ground.

00:12:19.479 --> 00:12:24.302
And that change is both welcome
and is happening very rapidly.

00:12:24.326 --> 00:12:25.711
But it's still not enough,

00:12:25.735 --> 00:12:28.002
and the political will
is still not enough.

00:12:28.433 --> 00:12:33.400
Let me come back to President Tong
and his people in Kiribati.

00:12:34.035 --> 00:12:40.826
They actually could be able to live
on their island and have a solution,

00:12:40.850 --> 00:12:43.071
but it would take a lot of political will.

00:12:43.558 --> 00:12:47.706
President Tong told me
about his ambitious idea

00:12:47.730 --> 00:12:54.090
to either build up or even float
the little islands where his people live.

00:12:54.976 --> 00:12:59.042
This, of course, is beyond
the resources of Kiribati itself.

00:12:59.383 --> 00:13:03.114
It would require great solidarity
and support from other countries,

00:13:03.138 --> 00:13:07.360
and it would require
the kind of imaginative idea

00:13:07.384 --> 00:13:11.937
that we bring together when we want
to have a space station in the air.

00:13:12.394 --> 00:13:17.249
But wouldn't it be wonderful
to have this engineering wonder

00:13:17.273 --> 00:13:20.806
and to allow a people to remain
in their sovereign territory,

00:13:20.830 --> 00:13:23.949
and be part of the community of nations?

00:13:23.973 --> 00:13:28.756
That is the kind of idea
that we should be thinking about.

00:13:29.639 --> 00:13:34.413
Yes, the challenges
of the transformation we need are big,

00:13:34.437 --> 00:13:36.985
but they can be solved.

00:13:37.009 --> 00:13:39.040
We are actually, as a people,

00:13:39.064 --> 00:13:42.358
very capable of coming together
to solve problems.

00:13:42.764 --> 00:13:46.398
I was very conscious of this
as I took part this year

00:13:46.422 --> 00:13:50.179
in commemoration of the 70th anniversary

00:13:50.203 --> 00:13:54.868
of the end of the Second
World War in 1945.

00:13:55.702 --> 00:13:58.303
1945 was an extraordinary year.

00:13:59.325 --> 00:14:01.931
It was a year when the world faced

00:14:01.955 --> 00:14:05.482
what must have seemed almost
insoluble problems --

00:14:05.506 --> 00:14:10.055
the devastation of the world wars,
particularly the Second World War;

00:14:10.079 --> 00:14:13.286
the fragile peace that had
been brought about;

00:14:13.310 --> 00:14:15.944
the need for a whole
economic regeneration.

00:14:16.601 --> 00:14:20.826
But the leaders of that time
didn't flinch from this.

00:14:20.850 --> 00:14:25.180
They had the capacity, they had
a sense of being driven by

00:14:25.204 --> 00:14:29.255
never again must the world
have this kind of problem.

00:14:29.279 --> 00:14:32.995
And they had to build structures
for peace and security.

00:14:33.019 --> 00:14:36.480
And what did we get?
What did they achieve?

00:14:36.504 --> 00:14:39.123
The Charter of the United Nations,

00:14:39.147 --> 00:14:42.698
the Bretton Woods institutions,
as they're called, The World Bank,

00:14:42.722 --> 00:14:45.159
and the International Monetary Fund.

00:14:45.183 --> 00:14:48.557
A Marshall Plan for Europe,
a devastated Europe,

00:14:48.581 --> 00:14:50.503
to reconstruct it.

00:14:50.527 --> 00:14:52.588
And indeed a few years later,

00:14:52.612 --> 00:14:55.765
the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

00:14:56.322 --> 00:15:01.936
2015 is a year that is similar
in its importance

00:15:01.960 --> 00:15:06.811
to 1945, with similar challenges
and similar potential.

00:15:07.335 --> 00:15:10.358
There will be two big summits this year:

00:15:10.382 --> 00:15:13.161
the first one, in September in New York,

00:15:13.185 --> 00:15:16.470
is the summit for the sustainable
development goals.

00:15:17.029 --> 00:15:22.507
And then the summit in Paris in December,
to give us a climate agreement.

00:15:23.323 --> 00:15:29.650
The sustainable development goals
are intended to help countries

00:15:29.674 --> 00:15:33.784
to live sustainably,
in tune with Mother Earth,

00:15:33.808 --> 00:15:39.134
not to take out of Mother Earth
and destroy ecosystems,

00:15:39.158 --> 00:15:42.772
but rather, to live in harmony
with Mother Earth,

00:15:42.796 --> 00:15:46.625
by living under sustainable development.

00:15:46.649 --> 00:15:49.022
And the sustainable development goals

00:15:49.046 --> 00:15:51.431
will come into operation for all countries

00:15:51.455 --> 00:15:54.327
on January 1, 2016.

00:15:54.772 --> 00:15:55.949
The climate agreement --

00:15:55.973 --> 00:15:57.489
a binding climate agreement --

00:15:57.513 --> 00:16:01.177
is needed because
of the scientific evidence

00:16:01.201 --> 00:16:04.118
that we're on a trajectory
for about a four-degree world

00:16:04.142 --> 00:16:07.630
and we have to change course
to stay below two degrees.

00:16:07.991 --> 00:16:13.515
So we need to take steps
that will be monitored and reviewed,

00:16:13.539 --> 00:16:17.937
so that we can keep increasing
the ambition of how we cut emissions,

00:16:17.961 --> 00:16:21.077
and how we move more rapidly
to renewable energy,

00:16:21.101 --> 00:16:24.104
so that we have a safe world.

00:16:27.623 --> 00:16:33.806
The reality is that this issue
is much too important

00:16:33.830 --> 00:16:37.393
to be left to politicians
and to the United Nations.

00:16:37.417 --> 00:16:38.418
(Laughter)

00:16:38.442 --> 00:16:40.020
It's an issue for all of us,

00:16:40.044 --> 00:16:44.008
and it's an issue where we need
more and more momentum.

00:16:44.869 --> 00:16:48.354
Indeed, the face of
the environmentalist has changed,

00:16:48.378 --> 00:16:50.687
because of the justice dimension.

00:16:50.711 --> 00:16:53.931
It's now an issue
for faith-based organizations,

00:16:53.955 --> 00:16:57.127
under very good leadership
from Pope Francis,

00:16:57.151 --> 00:16:58.923
and indeed, the Church of England,

00:16:58.947 --> 00:17:01.390
which is divesting from fossil fuels.

00:17:01.414 --> 00:17:05.172
It's an issue for the business community,

00:17:05.196 --> 00:17:06.600
and the good news is

00:17:06.624 --> 00:17:09.534
that the business community
is changing very rapidly --

00:17:09.558 --> 00:17:11.743
except for the fossil fuel industries --

00:17:11.767 --> 00:17:13.362
(Laughter)

00:17:13.386 --> 00:17:16.682
Even they are beginning
to slightly change their language --

00:17:16.706 --> 00:17:17.687
but only slightly.

00:17:17.711 --> 00:17:22.402
But business is not only moving rapidly
to the benefits of renewable energy,

00:17:22.426 --> 00:17:25.149
but is urging politicians
to give them more signals,

00:17:25.173 --> 00:17:27.148
so that they can move even more rapidly.

00:17:27.172 --> 00:17:29.173
It's an issue for the trade
union movement.

00:17:29.197 --> 00:17:31.220
It's an issue for the women's movement.

00:17:31.244 --> 00:17:33.322
It's an issue for young people.

00:17:33.346 --> 00:17:39.148
I was very struck when I learned
that Jibreel Khazan,

00:17:39.172 --> 00:17:44.816
one of the Greensboro Four who had
taken part in the Woolworth sit-ins,

00:17:44.840 --> 00:17:46.354
said quite recently that

00:17:46.378 --> 00:17:52.380
climate change is the lunch counter
moment for young people.

00:17:52.404 --> 00:17:56.692
So, lunch counter moment
for young people of the 21st century --

00:17:56.716 --> 00:18:01.057
the sort of real human rights issue
of the 21st century,

00:18:01.081 --> 00:18:03.851
because he said it is
the greatest challenge

00:18:03.875 --> 00:18:07.467
to humanity and justice in our world.

00:18:08.349 --> 00:18:12.455
I recall very much
the Climate March last September,

00:18:12.479 --> 00:18:14.280
and that was a huge momentum,

00:18:14.304 --> 00:18:17.266
not just in New York,
but all around the world.

00:18:17.290 --> 00:18:19.560
and we have to build on that.

00:18:19.584 --> 00:18:22.695
I was marching with some
of The Elders family,

00:18:22.719 --> 00:18:27.746
and I saw a placard
a little bit away from me,

00:18:27.770 --> 00:18:29.724
but we were wedged so closely together --

00:18:29.748 --> 00:18:33.423
because after all, there were 400,000
people out in the streets of New York --

00:18:33.447 --> 00:18:35.360
so I couldn't quite get to that placard,

00:18:35.384 --> 00:18:38.465
I would have just liked to have been
able to step behind it,

00:18:38.489 --> 00:18:40.935
because it said, "Angry Grannies!"

00:18:40.959 --> 00:18:42.282
(Laughter)

00:18:42.306 --> 00:18:43.760
That's what I felt.

00:18:43.784 --> 00:18:47.757
And I have five grandchildren now,

00:18:47.781 --> 00:18:52.069
I feel very happy as an Irish grandmother
to have five grandchildren,

00:18:52.093 --> 00:18:55.136
and I think about their world,

00:18:55.160 --> 00:18:58.321
and what it will be
like when they will share that world

00:18:58.345 --> 00:19:02.391
with about 9 billion other people in 2050.

00:19:03.532 --> 00:19:08.187
We know that inevitably it will
be a climate-constrained world,

00:19:08.211 --> 00:19:11.060
because of the emissions
we've already put up there,

00:19:11.084 --> 00:19:16.481
but it could be a world that is much
more equal and much fairer,

00:19:16.505 --> 00:19:19.087
and much better for health,
and better for jobs

00:19:19.111 --> 00:19:21.083
and better for energy security,

00:19:21.107 --> 00:19:22.934
than the world we have now,

00:19:22.958 --> 00:19:29.958
if we have switched sufficiently
and early enough to renewable energy,

00:19:30.180 --> 00:19:32.612
and no one is left behind.

00:19:32.636 --> 00:19:35.031
No one is left behind.

00:19:35.694 --> 00:19:39.274
And just as we've been
looking back this year --

00:19:39.298 --> 00:19:44.805
in 2015 to 1945, looking back 70 years --

00:19:44.829 --> 00:19:47.393
I would like to think
that they will look back,

00:19:47.417 --> 00:19:52.266
that world will look back
35 years from 2050,

00:19:52.290 --> 00:19:55.164
35 years to 2015,

00:19:55.188 --> 00:19:58.006
and that they will say,

00:19:58.030 --> 00:20:02.137
"Weren't they good
to do what they did in 2015?

00:20:02.161 --> 00:20:07.636
We really appreciate that they took
the decisions that made a difference,

00:20:07.660 --> 00:20:10.598
and that put the world
on the right pathway,

00:20:10.622 --> 00:20:13.328
and we benefit now from that pathway,"

00:20:13.352 --> 00:20:17.233
that they will feel that somehow
we took our responsibilities,

00:20:17.257 --> 00:20:21.416
we did what was done
in 1945 in similar terms,

00:20:21.440 --> 00:20:23.861
we didn't miss the opportunity,

00:20:23.885 --> 00:20:26.067
we lived up to our responsibilities.

00:20:26.091 --> 00:20:29.263
That's what this year is about.

00:20:29.646 --> 00:20:30.996
And somehow for me,

00:20:31.020 --> 00:20:35.314
it's captured in words of somebody
that I admired very much.

00:20:35.338 --> 00:20:37.671
She was a mentor of mine,
she was a friend,

00:20:37.695 --> 00:20:39.643
she died much too young,

00:20:39.667 --> 00:20:41.672
she was an extraordinary personality,

00:20:41.696 --> 00:20:44.180
a great champion of the environment:

00:20:44.204 --> 00:20:46.028
Wangari Maathai.

00:20:46.585 --> 00:20:49.211
Wangari said once,

00:20:49.235 --> 00:20:51.189
"In the course of history,

00:20:51.213 --> 00:20:55.224
there comes a time
when humanity is called upon

00:20:55.248 --> 00:20:59.999
to shift to a new level of consciousness,

00:21:00.023 --> 00:21:03.480
to reach a higher moral ground."

00:21:04.093 --> 00:21:06.012
And that's what we have to do.

00:21:06.036 --> 00:21:09.324
We have to reach
a new level of consciousness,

00:21:09.348 --> 00:21:11.315
a higher moral ground.

00:21:11.749 --> 00:21:15.590
And we have to do it this year
in those two big summits.

00:21:16.066 --> 00:21:19.664
And that won't happen unless
we have the momentum

00:21:19.688 --> 00:21:22.835
from people around the world who say:

00:21:22.859 --> 00:21:24.379
"We want action now,

00:21:24.403 --> 00:21:25.974
we want to change course,

00:21:25.998 --> 00:21:27.371
we want a safe world,

00:21:27.395 --> 00:21:29.570
a safe world for future generations,

00:21:29.594 --> 00:21:32.202
a safe world for our children
and our grandchildren,

00:21:32.226 --> 00:21:34.497
and we're all in this together."

00:21:34.521 --> 00:21:35.681
Thank you.

00:21:35.705 --> 00:21:40.950
(Applause)

title: 4 powerful poems about Parkinson's and growing older
transcript: When I was only three or four, I fell in love with poetry, with the rhythms and the music of language; with the power of metaphor and of imagery, poetry being the essence of communication — the discipline, the distillation. And all these years later, the poems I'll read today are from my just-finished seventh book of poetry.Well, five years ago, I was diagnosed with Parkinson's disease. Though there's no cure yet, advances in treatment are really impressive. But you can imagine that I was appalled to learn that women are largely left out of research trials, despite gender-specific medical findings having demonstrated that we are not actually just small men —(Laughter)who happen to have different reproductive systems. Gender-specific medicine is good for men, too.But you bring to a crisis the person you already are, including the, yes, momentum that you've learned to invoke through passionate caring and through action, both of which require but also create energy. So as an activist, I began working with the Parkinson's Disease Foundation — that's pdf.org — to create a major initiative to put women on the Parkinson's disease map. And as a poet, I began working with this subject matter, finding it tragic, hilarious, sometimes even joyful. I do not feel diminished by Parkinson's; I feel distilled by it, and I actually very much like the woman I'm distilling into."No Signs of Struggle"Growing small requires enormity of will: just sitting still in the doctor's waiting room watching the future shuffle in and out, watching it stoop; stare at you while you try not to look. Rare is an exchange: a smile of brief, wry recognition.You are the new kid on the block. Everyone here was you once. You are still learning that growing small requires a largeness of spirit you can't fit into yet: acceptance of irritating help from those who love you; giving way and over, but not up.You've swallowed hard the contents of the "Drink Me" bottle, and felt yourself shrink. Now, familiar furniture looms, floors tilt, and doorknobs yield only when wrestled round with both hands. It demands colossal patience, all this growing small: your diminished sleep at night, your handwriting, your voice, your height.You are more the incredible shrinking woman than the Buddhist mystic, serene, making do with less. Less is not always more. Yet in this emptying space, space glimmers, becoming visible. Here is a place behind the eyes of those accustomed by what some would call diminishment.It is a place of merciless poetry, a gift of presence previously ignored, drowned in the daily clutter. Here every gesture needs intention, is alive with consciousness. Such quiet beauty here, in these, my soft-voiced, stiff-limbed people; such resolve masked by each placid face. Flattering, that.So fill in the forms, drill through the answers, trill out a blithe spirit.And slice me, dice me, spread me on your slides. Find what I'm trying to tell you.Earn me, learn me, scan me, squint through your lens. Uncover what I'd hint at if I could.Be my guest, do your best, harvest me, track the clues. Share me, hear me:I want to be used I want to be used I want to be used up.(Applause)(Applause ends)And this one's called "The Ghost Light."Lit from within is the sole secure way to traverse dark matter. Some life forms — certain mushrooms, snails, jellyfish, worms — glow bioluminescent, and people as well; we emit infra-red light from our most lucent selves. Our tragedy is we can't see it.We see by reflecting. We need biofluorescence to show our true colors. External illumination can distort, though. When gravity bends light, huge galaxy clusters can act as telescopes, elongating background images of star systems to faint arcs — a lensing effect like viewing distant street lamps through a glass of wine.A glass of wine or two now makes me weave as if acting the drunkard's part; as if, besotted with unrequited love for the dynamic Turner canvasses spied out by the Hubble, I could lurch down a city street set without provoking every pedestrian walk-on stare.Stare as long as you need to. subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.775 --> 00:00:15.219
When I was only three or four,

00:00:15.243 --> 00:00:17.711
I fell in love with poetry,

00:00:17.735 --> 00:00:20.846
with the rhythms
and the music of language;

00:00:20.870 --> 00:00:24.513
with the power of metaphor and of imagery,

00:00:24.537 --> 00:00:27.299
poetry being the essence
of communication --

00:00:27.323 --> 00:00:30.030
the discipline, the distillation.

00:00:30.957 --> 00:00:33.919
And all these years later,
the poems I'll read today

00:00:33.943 --> 00:00:37.244
are from my just-finished
seventh book of poetry.

00:00:38.157 --> 00:00:42.284
Well, five years ago, I was diagnosed
with Parkinson's disease.

00:00:42.832 --> 00:00:44.752
Though there's no cure yet,

00:00:44.776 --> 00:00:47.562
advances in treatment
are really impressive.

00:00:47.943 --> 00:00:50.933
But you can imagine
that I was appalled to learn

00:00:50.957 --> 00:00:55.451
that women are largely
left out of research trials,

00:00:55.475 --> 00:00:58.996
despite gender-specific
medical findings having demonstrated

00:00:59.020 --> 00:01:01.679
that we are not actually just small men --

00:01:01.704 --> 00:01:03.800
(Laughter)

00:01:03.824 --> 00:01:07.076
who happen to have
different reproductive systems.

00:01:07.100 --> 00:01:09.929
Gender-specific medicine
is good for men, too.

00:01:10.283 --> 00:01:15.036
But you bring to a crisis
the person you already are,

00:01:15.060 --> 00:01:18.933
including the, yes, momentum
that you've learned to invoke

00:01:18.957 --> 00:01:22.266
through passionate caring
and through action,

00:01:22.290 --> 00:01:26.658
both of which require
but also create energy.

00:01:27.428 --> 00:01:31.714
So as an activist, I began working
with the Parkinson's Disease Foundation --

00:01:31.738 --> 00:01:33.919
that's pdf.org --

00:01:33.943 --> 00:01:40.682
to create a major initiative to put women
on the Parkinson's disease map.

00:01:41.777 --> 00:01:45.002
And as a poet, I began working
with this subject matter,

00:01:45.026 --> 00:01:49.750
finding it tragic, hilarious,
sometimes even joyful.

00:01:50.094 --> 00:01:52.681
I do not feel diminished by Parkinson's;

00:01:52.705 --> 00:01:55.330
I feel distilled by it,

00:01:55.354 --> 00:01:59.792
and I actually very much
like the woman I'm distilling into.

00:02:01.486 --> 00:02:03.387
"No Signs of Struggle"

00:02:04.527 --> 00:02:08.577
Growing small requires enormity of will:

00:02:08.601 --> 00:02:11.189
just sitting still
in the doctor's waiting room

00:02:11.213 --> 00:02:14.799
watching the future shuffle in and out,

00:02:14.823 --> 00:02:17.566
watching it stoop; stare at you

00:02:17.590 --> 00:02:19.552
while you try not to look.

00:02:20.171 --> 00:02:21.814
Rare is an exchange:

00:02:21.838 --> 00:02:24.981
a smile of brief, wry recognition.

00:02:25.875 --> 00:02:27.674
You are the new kid on the block.

00:02:28.150 --> 00:02:30.310
Everyone here was you once.

00:02:30.749 --> 00:02:34.956
You are still learning that growing small
requires a largeness of spirit

00:02:34.980 --> 00:02:37.439
you can't fit into yet:

00:02:37.463 --> 00:02:41.412
acceptance of irritating help
from those who love you;

00:02:41.436 --> 00:02:44.520
giving way and over, but not up.

00:02:45.452 --> 00:02:48.680
You've swallowed hard the contents
of the "Drink Me" bottle,

00:02:48.704 --> 00:02:50.889
and felt yourself shrink.

00:02:51.534 --> 00:02:54.277
Now, familiar furniture looms,

00:02:54.301 --> 00:02:59.087
floors tilt, and doorknobs yield only
when wrestled round with both hands.

00:02:59.643 --> 00:03:04.513
It demands colossal patience,
all this growing small:

00:03:04.537 --> 00:03:06.433
your diminished sleep at night,

00:03:06.457 --> 00:03:09.886
your handwriting, your voice, your height.

00:03:10.626 --> 00:03:13.851
You are more the incredible
shrinking woman

00:03:13.875 --> 00:03:17.798
than the Buddhist mystic,
serene, making do with less.

00:03:17.822 --> 00:03:20.603
Less is not always more.

00:03:21.518 --> 00:03:26.098
Yet in this emptying space,
space glimmers,

00:03:26.122 --> 00:03:27.756
becoming visible.

00:03:28.073 --> 00:03:31.432
Here is a place behind the eyes
of those accustomed

00:03:31.456 --> 00:03:34.725
by what some would call diminishment.

00:03:35.426 --> 00:03:39.101
It is a place of merciless poetry,

00:03:39.125 --> 00:03:42.444
a gift of presence previously ignored,

00:03:42.468 --> 00:03:44.537
drowned in the daily clutter.

00:03:45.315 --> 00:03:48.396
Here every gesture needs intention,

00:03:48.420 --> 00:03:50.426
is alive with consciousness.

00:03:50.844 --> 00:03:52.304
Nothing is automatic.

00:03:53.150 --> 00:03:56.619
You can spot it
in the provocation of a button,

00:03:56.643 --> 00:03:58.856
an arm poking at a sleeve,

00:03:58.880 --> 00:04:03.229
a balancing act at a night-time curb
while negotiating the dark.

00:04:04.091 --> 00:04:07.125
Feats of such modest valor,

00:04:07.149 --> 00:04:12.453
who would suspect them to be exercises
in an intimate, fierce discipline,

00:04:12.477 --> 00:04:15.778
a metaphysics of being relentlessly aware?

00:04:16.625 --> 00:04:19.410
Such understated power here,

00:04:19.434 --> 00:04:23.722
in these tottering dancers
who exert stupendous effort

00:04:23.746 --> 00:04:26.832
on tasks most view as insignificant.

00:04:27.530 --> 00:04:30.871
Such quiet beauty here, in these,

00:04:30.895 --> 00:04:35.168
my soft-voiced, stiff-limbed people;

00:04:35.192 --> 00:04:38.890
such resolve masked by each placid face.

00:04:39.895 --> 00:04:44.488
There is immensity required
in growing small,

00:04:44.512 --> 00:04:47.523
so bent on such unbending grace.

00:04:47.978 --> 00:04:54.277
(Applause)

00:04:54.301 --> 00:04:55.879
Thank you.

00:04:55.903 --> 00:04:59.086
This one is called
"On Donating My Brain to Science."

00:04:59.110 --> 00:05:00.302
(Laughter)

00:05:01.016 --> 00:05:02.212
Not a problem.

00:05:03.307 --> 00:05:06.820
Skip over all the pages
reassuring religious people.

00:05:07.238 --> 00:05:10.994
Already a universal donor:
kidneys, corneas, liver, lungs,

00:05:11.018 --> 00:05:13.240
tissue, heart, veins, whatever.

00:05:14.055 --> 00:05:19.533
Odd that the modest brain never
imagined its unique value in research,

00:05:19.557 --> 00:05:23.871
maybe saving someone else from what it is
they're not quite sure I have.

00:05:23.895 --> 00:05:25.128
Flattering, that.

00:05:25.631 --> 00:05:27.776
So fill in the forms,

00:05:27.800 --> 00:05:29.659
drill through the answers,

00:05:29.683 --> 00:05:31.646
trill out a blithe spirit.

00:05:31.979 --> 00:05:35.958
And slice me, dice me,
spread me on your slides.

00:05:36.661 --> 00:05:38.624
Find what I'm trying to tell you.

00:05:38.952 --> 00:05:43.949
Earn me, learn me, scan me,
squint through your lens.

00:05:43.973 --> 00:05:46.652
Uncover what I'd hint at if I could.

00:05:46.676 --> 00:05:51.140
Be my guest, do your best,
harvest me, track the clues.

00:05:51.164 --> 00:05:53.638
This was a good brain while alive.

00:05:53.662 --> 00:05:56.018
This was a brain that paid its dues.

00:05:56.042 --> 00:06:00.933
So slice me, dice me,
smear me on your slides,

00:06:00.957 --> 00:06:04.478
stain me, explain me, drain me like a cup.

00:06:04.502 --> 00:06:06.578
Share me, hear me:

00:06:06.602 --> 00:06:09.202
I want to be used
I want to be used

00:06:09.226 --> 00:06:11.272
I want to be used
up.

00:06:12.353 --> 00:06:14.891
(Applause)

00:06:19.393 --> 00:06:21.218
(Applause ends)

00:06:21.627 --> 00:06:24.489
And this one's called "The Ghost Light."

00:06:26.187 --> 00:06:29.737
Lit from within is the sole secure way

00:06:29.761 --> 00:06:31.755
to traverse dark matter.

00:06:32.382 --> 00:06:37.379
Some life forms -- certain mushrooms,
snails, jellyfish, worms --

00:06:37.403 --> 00:06:39.675
glow bioluminescent,

00:06:39.699 --> 00:06:41.468
and people as well;

00:06:41.492 --> 00:06:45.744
we emit infra-red light
from our most lucent selves.

00:06:46.634 --> 00:06:49.560
Our tragedy is we can't see it.

00:06:50.364 --> 00:06:52.216
We see by reflecting.

00:06:52.930 --> 00:06:56.659
We need biofluorescence
to show our true colors.

00:06:57.358 --> 00:07:00.461
External illumination can distort, though.

00:07:00.485 --> 00:07:02.487
When gravity bends light,

00:07:02.511 --> 00:07:06.120
huge galaxy clusters
can act as telescopes,

00:07:06.144 --> 00:07:11.321
elongating background images
of star systems to faint arcs --

00:07:11.345 --> 00:07:12.499
a lensing effect

00:07:12.523 --> 00:07:16.466
like viewing distant street lamps
through a glass of wine.

00:07:17.493 --> 00:07:20.200
A glass of wine or two now makes me weave

00:07:20.224 --> 00:07:23.086
as if acting the drunkard's part;

00:07:23.110 --> 00:07:26.456
as if, besotted with unrequited love

00:07:26.480 --> 00:07:30.565
for the dynamic Turner canvasses
spied out by the Hubble,

00:07:30.589 --> 00:07:32.870
I could lurch down a city street set

00:07:32.894 --> 00:07:36.813
without provoking
every pedestrian walk-on stare.

00:07:37.882 --> 00:07:39.882
Stare as long as you need to.

00:07:40.400 --> 00:07:45.799
If you think about it, walking,
even standing, is illogical --

00:07:45.823 --> 00:07:47.799
such tiny things, feet! --

00:07:47.823 --> 00:07:49.740
(Laughter)

00:07:49.764 --> 00:07:53.675
especially when one's body
is not al dente anymore.

00:07:53.699 --> 00:07:57.285
(Laughter)

00:07:57.687 --> 00:08:00.809
Besides, creature of extremes and excess,

00:08:00.833 --> 00:08:03.869
I've always thought Apollo
beautiful but boring,

00:08:03.893 --> 00:08:05.877
and a bit of a dumb blonde.

00:08:06.729 --> 00:08:09.706
Dionysians don't do balance.

00:08:10.881 --> 00:08:14.532
Balance, in other words,
has never been my strong point.

00:08:15.062 --> 00:08:16.230
But I digress.

00:08:16.254 --> 00:08:17.469
More and more these days,

00:08:17.493 --> 00:08:20.491
digression seems
the most direct route through

00:08:20.515 --> 00:08:22.592
from where I've lost or found myself

00:08:22.616 --> 00:08:26.307
out of place, mind, turn, time.

00:08:27.180 --> 00:08:31.516
Place your foot just so,
mind how you turn:

00:08:31.540 --> 00:08:34.317
too swift a swivel can bring you down.

00:08:35.164 --> 00:08:38.092
Take your time ushering the audience out,

00:08:38.116 --> 00:08:40.148
saying goodbye to the actors.

00:08:41.006 --> 00:08:42.157
The ghost light

00:08:42.181 --> 00:08:43.967
is what they call the single bulb

00:08:43.991 --> 00:08:47.592
hanging above the bare stage
in an empty theater.

00:08:48.613 --> 00:08:50.926
In the empty theater of such a night,

00:08:50.950 --> 00:08:54.768
waking to meet no external radiance,

00:08:54.792 --> 00:08:57.984
this is the final struggle left to win,

00:08:58.008 --> 00:09:01.243
this the sole beacon
to beckon the darkness in

00:09:01.267 --> 00:09:03.912
and let the rest begin,

00:09:03.936 --> 00:09:08.889
this the lens through which at last
to see both Self and Other

00:09:08.913 --> 00:09:13.533
arrayed with the bright stain
of original sin:

00:09:13.557 --> 00:09:15.009
lit from within.

00:09:16.828 --> 00:09:23.783
(Applause)

00:09:24.683 --> 00:09:26.065
And this is the last one.

00:09:26.597 --> 00:09:28.061
"This Dark Hour"

00:09:29.471 --> 00:09:31.986
Late summer, 4 A.M.

00:09:32.632 --> 00:09:34.978
The rain slows to a stop,

00:09:35.002 --> 00:09:37.250
dripping still from the broad leaves

00:09:37.274 --> 00:09:40.461
of blue hostas unseen
in the garden's dark.

00:09:41.217 --> 00:09:44.911
Barefoot, careful
on the slick slate slabs,

00:09:44.935 --> 00:09:48.218
I need no light, I know the way,

00:09:48.242 --> 00:09:50.121
stoop by the mint bed,

00:09:50.145 --> 00:09:52.950
scoop a fistful of moist earth,

00:09:52.974 --> 00:09:54.682
then grope for a chair,

00:09:54.706 --> 00:09:57.360
spread a shawl, and sit,

00:09:57.384 --> 00:10:01.142
breathing in the wet green August air.

00:10:02.198 --> 00:10:05.188
This is the small, still hour

00:10:05.212 --> 00:10:09.026
before the newspaper
lands in the vestibule like a grenade,

00:10:09.050 --> 00:10:13.621
the phone shrills, the computer screen
blinks and glares awake.

00:10:14.601 --> 00:10:16.781
There is this hour:

00:10:16.805 --> 00:10:20.781
poem in my head, soil in my hand:

00:10:20.805 --> 00:10:22.751
unnamable fullness.

00:10:23.620 --> 00:10:26.203
This hour, when blood of my blood

00:10:26.227 --> 00:10:30.259
bone of bone, child grown
to manhood now --

00:10:30.283 --> 00:10:35.747
stranger, intimate,
not distant but apart --

00:10:35.771 --> 00:10:39.505
lies safe, off dreaming melodies

00:10:39.529 --> 00:10:43.058
while love sleeps, safe, in his arms.

00:10:43.693 --> 00:10:46.298
To have come to this place,

00:10:46.322 --> 00:10:48.413
lived to this moment:

00:10:48.437 --> 00:10:50.552
immeasurable lightness.

00:10:51.350 --> 00:10:54.271
The density of black starts to blur umber.

00:10:54.747 --> 00:10:57.725
Tentative, a cardinal's coloratura,

00:10:57.749 --> 00:10:59.760
then the mourning dove's elegy.

00:11:00.348 --> 00:11:02.738
Sable glimmers toward grey;

00:11:02.762 --> 00:11:05.930
objects emerge, trailing shadows;

00:11:05.954 --> 00:11:07.929
night ages toward day.

00:11:08.498 --> 00:11:09.964
The city stirs.

00:11:10.916 --> 00:11:14.816
There will be other dawns,
nights, gaudy noons.

00:11:15.418 --> 00:11:17.375
Likely, I'll lose my way.

00:11:17.818 --> 00:11:20.230
There will be stumbling, falling,

00:11:20.254 --> 00:11:21.495
cursing the dark.

00:11:22.448 --> 00:11:24.068
Whatever comes,

00:11:24.092 --> 00:11:28.039
there was this hour when nothing mattered,

00:11:28.063 --> 00:11:30.744
all was unbearably dear.

00:11:31.848 --> 00:11:34.074
And when I'm done with daylights,

00:11:34.098 --> 00:11:39.059
should those who loved me
grieve too long a while,

00:11:39.083 --> 00:11:42.312
let them remember that I had this hour --

00:11:42.336 --> 00:11:45.944
this dark, perfect hour --

00:11:45.968 --> 00:11:47.370
and smile.

00:11:48.376 --> 00:11:49.530
Thank you.

00:11:49.554 --> 00:11:55.906
(Applause)

title: Alzheimer's is not normal aging — and we can cure it
transcript: In the year 1901, a woman called Auguste was taken to a medical asylum in Frankfurt. Auguste was delusional and couldn't remember even the most basic details of her life. Her doctor was called Alois. Alois didn't know how to help Auguste, but he watched over her until, sadly, she passed away in 1906. After she died, Alois performed an autopsy and found strange plaques and tangles in Auguste's brain — the likes of which he'd never seen before.Now here's the even more striking thing. If Auguste had instead been alive today, we could offer her no more help than Alois was able to 114 years ago. Alois was Dr. Alois Alzheimer. And Auguste Deter was the first patient to be diagnosed with what we now call Alzheimer's disease. Since 1901, medicine has advanced greatly. We've discovered antibiotics and vaccines to protect us from infections, many treatments for cancer, antiretrovirals for HIV, statins for heart disease and much more. But we've made essentially no progress at all in treating Alzheimer's disease.I'm part of a team of scientists who has been working to find a cure for Alzheimer's for over a decade. So I think about this all the time. Alzheimer's now affects 40 million people worldwide. But by 2050, it will affect 150 million people — which, by the way, will include many of you. If you're hoping to live to be 85 or older, your chance of getting Alzheimer's will be almost one in two. In other words, odds are you'll spend your golden years either suffering from Alzheimer's or helping to look after a friend or loved one with Alzheimer's. Already in the United States alone, Alzheimer's care costs 200 billion dollars every year. One out of every five Medicare dollars get spent on Alzheimer's. It is today the most expensive disease, and costs are projected to increase fivefold by 2050, as the baby boomer generation ages.It may surprise you that, put simply, Alzheimer's is one of the biggest medical and social challenges of our generation. But we've done relatively little to address it. Today, of the top 10 causes of death worldwide, Alzheimer's is the only one we cannot prevent, cure or even slow down. We understand less about the science of Alzheimer's than other diseases because we've invested less time and money into researching it. The US government spends 10 times more every year on cancer research than on Alzheimer's despite the fact that Alzheimer's costs us more and causes a similar number of deaths each year as cancer.The lack of resources stems from a more fundamental cause: a lack of awareness. Because here's what few people know but everyone should: Alzheimer's is a disease, and we can cure it. For most of the past 114 years, everyone, including scientists, mistakenly confused Alzheimer's with aging. We thought that becoming senile was a normal and inevitable part of getting old. But we only have to look at a picture of a healthy aged brain compared to the brain of an Alzheimer's patient to see the real physical damage caused by this disease. As well as triggering severe loss of memory and mental abilities, the damage to the brain caused by Alzheimer's significantly reduces life expectancy and is always fatal.Remember Dr. Alzheimer found strange plaques and tangles in Auguste's brain a century ago. For almost a century, we didn't know much about these. Today we know they're made from protein molecules. You can imagine a protein molecule as a piece of paper that normally folds into an elaborate piece of origami. There are spots on the paper that are sticky. And when it folds correctly, these sticky bits end up on the inside. But sometimes things go wrong, and some sticky bits are on the outside. This causes the protein molecules to stick to each other, forming clumps that eventually become large plaques and tangles. That's what we see in the brains of Alzheimer's patients.We've spent the past 10 years at the University of Cambridge trying to understand how this malfunction works. There are many steps, and identifying which step to try to block is complex — like defusing a bomb. Cutting one wire might do nothing. Cutting others might make the bomb explore. We have to find the right step to block, and then create a drug that does it.Until recently, we for the most part have been cutting wires and hoping for the best. But now we've got together a diverse group of people — medics, biologists, geneticists, chemists, physicists, engineers and mathematicians. And together, we've managed to identify a critical step in the process and are now testing a new class of drugs which would specifically block this step and stop the disease.Now let me show you some of our latest results. No one outside of our lab has seen these yet. Let's look at some videos of what happened when we tested these new drugs in worms. So these are healthy worms, and you can see they're moving around normally. These worms, on the other hand, have protein molecules sticking together inside them — like humans with Alzheimer's. And you can see they're clearly sick. But if we give our new drugs to these worms at an early stage, then we see that they're healthy, and they live a normal lifespan. This is just an initial positive result, but research like this shows us that Alzheimer's is a disease that we can understand and we can cure.After 114 years of waiting, there's finally real hope for what can be achieved in the next 10 or 20 years. But to grow that hope, to finally beat Alzheimer's, we need help. This isn't about scientists like me — it's about you. We need you to raise awareness that Alzheimer's is a disease and that if we try, we can beat it. That was essential for advancing treatment for HIV in the late 1980s. Today, we see that same drive to beat cancer. But Alzheimer's patients are often unable to speak up for themselves. And their families, the hidden victims, caring for their loved ones night and day, are often too worn out to go out and advocate for change. So, it really is down to you. Alzheimer's isn't, for the most part, a genetic disease. Everyone with a brain is at risk. Today, there are 40 million patients like Auguste, who can't create the change they need for themselves. Help speak up for them, and help demand a cure.Thank you.(Applause)

00:00:12.758 --> 00:00:14.574
In the year 1901,

00:00:14.598 --> 00:00:18.078

00:00:18.918 --> 00:00:20.454
Auguste was delusional

00:00:20.478 --> 00:00:23.478
and couldn't remember
even the most basic details of her life.

00:00:24.238 --> 00:00:26.358
Her doctor was called Alois.

00:00:27.798 --> 00:00:30.054
Alois didn't know how to help Auguste,

00:00:30.078 --> 00:00:33.598
but he watched over her until,
sadly, she passed away in 1906.

00:00:34.478 --> 00:00:37.214
After she died, Alois performed an autopsy

00:00:37.238 --> 00:00:40.454
and found strange plaques
and tangles in Auguste's brain --

00:00:40.478 --> 00:00:42.814
the likes of which he'd never seen before.

00:00:42.838 --> 00:00:44.998
Now here's the even more striking thing.

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:48.918
If Auguste had instead been alive today,

00:00:49.478 --> 00:00:55.238
we could offer her no more help
than Alois was able to 114 years ago.

00:00:56.038 --> 00:00:59.598
Alois was Dr. Alois Alzheimer.

00:01:00.478 --> 00:01:02.614
And Auguste Deter

00:01:02.638 --> 00:01:06.878
was the first patient to be diagnosed with
what we now call Alzheimer's disease.

00:01:07.638 --> 00:01:10.598
Since 1901, medicine has advanced greatly.

00:01:11.158 --> 00:01:15.094
We've discovered antibiotics and vaccines
to protect us from infections,

00:01:15.118 --> 00:01:18.974
many treatments for cancer,
antiretrovirals for HIV,

00:01:18.998 --> 00:01:21.478
statins for heart disease and much more.

00:01:22.854 --> 00:01:29.719
But we've made essentially no progress
at all in treating Alzheimer's disease.

00:01:30.398 --> 00:01:31.934
I'm part of a team of scientists

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:35.244
who has been working to find
a cure for Alzheimer's for over a decade.

00:01:35.758 --> 00:01:38.214
So I think about this all the time.

00:01:38.238 --> 00:01:41.838
Alzheimer's now affects
40 million people worldwide.

00:01:42.318 --> 00:01:47.518
But by 2050, it will affect
150 million people --

00:01:48.318 --> 00:01:51.478
which, by the way,
will include many of you.

00:01:52.998 --> 00:01:55.998
If you're hoping
to live to be 85 or older,

00:01:57.118 --> 00:02:01.798
your chance of getting Alzheimer's
will be almost one in two.

00:02:03.558 --> 00:02:06.774
In other words, odds are
you'll spend your golden years

00:02:06.798 --> 00:02:09.014
either suffering from Alzheimer's

00:02:09.038 --> 00:02:13.358
or helping to look after a friend
or loved one with Alzheimer's.

00:02:14.438 --> 00:02:16.414
Already in the United States alone,

00:02:16.438 --> 00:02:20.717
Alzheimer's care costs
200 billion dollars every year.

00:02:21.877 --> 00:02:25.878
One out of every five
Medicare dollars get spent on Alzheimer's.

00:02:26.638 --> 00:02:29.774
It is today the most expensive disease,

00:02:29.798 --> 00:02:33.014
and costs are projected
to increase fivefold by 2050,

00:02:33.038 --> 00:02:35.198
as the baby boomer generation ages.

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:39.334
It may surprise you that, put simply,

00:02:39.358 --> 00:02:43.918
Alzheimer's is one of the biggest medical
and social challenges of our generation.

00:02:44.718 --> 00:02:46.998
But we've done relatively
little to address it.

00:02:47.918 --> 00:02:51.438
Today, of the top 10
causes of death worldwide,

00:02:51.838 --> 00:02:58.478
Alzheimer's is the only one

spends 10 times more every year
