00:01:47.078 --> 00:01:49.054
But the choice that we don't have

00:01:49.078 --> 00:01:51.398
is a no climate change future.

00:01:53.238 --> 00:01:55.214
Over the last two decades,

00:01:55.238 --> 00:01:59.094
our government negotiators
and policymakers have been coming together

00:01:59.118 --> 00:02:01.038
to discuss climate change,

00:02:01.398 --> 00:02:05.814
and they've been focused on
avoiding a two-degree centigrade warming

00:02:05.838 --> 00:02:07.638
above pre-industrial levels.

00:02:08.478 --> 00:02:12.054
That's the temperature that's associated
with dangerous impacts

00:02:12.078 --> 00:02:14.678
across a range of different indicators,

00:02:15.078 --> 00:02:17.694
to humans and to the environment.

00:02:17.718 --> 00:02:21.877
So two degrees centigrade
constitutes dangerous climate change.

00:02:22.502 --> 00:02:24.694
But dangerous climate change
can be subjective.

00:02:24.718 --> 00:02:27.014
So if we think about
an extreme weather event

00:02:27.038 --> 00:02:29.086
that might happen
in some part of the world,

00:02:29.398 --> 00:02:33.374
and if that happens in a part of the world
where there is good infrastructure,

00:02:33.398 --> 00:02:36.158
where there are people
that are well-insured and so on,

00:02:36.478 --> 00:02:40.094
then that impact can be disruptive.

00:02:40.118 --> 00:02:43.374
It can cause upset, it could cause cost.

00:02:43.398 --> 00:02:45.118
It could even cause some deaths.

00:02:45.558 --> 00:02:49.054
But if that exact same weather event
happens in a part of the world

00:02:49.078 --> 00:02:51.094
where there is poor infrastructure,

00:02:51.118 --> 00:02:53.334
or where people are not well-insured,

00:02:53.358 --> 00:02:55.774
or they're not having
good support networks,

00:02:55.798 --> 00:02:59.838
then that same climate change impact
could be devastating.

00:03:00.278 --> 00:03:03.814
It could cause a significant loss of home,

00:03:03.838 --> 00:03:06.838
but it could also cause
significant amounts of death.

00:03:07.758 --> 00:03:11.734
So this is a graph of the CO2 emissions
at the left-hand side

00:03:11.758 --> 00:03:13.574
from fossil fuel and industry,

00:03:13.598 --> 00:03:16.574
and time from before
the Industrial Revolution

00:03:16.598 --> 00:03:18.198
out towards the present day.

00:03:18.798 --> 00:03:21.254
And what's immediately striking about this

00:03:21.278 --> 00:03:24.318
is that emissions
have been growing exponentially.

00:03:25.118 --> 00:03:29.334
If we focus in on a shorter
period of time from 1950,

00:03:29.358 --> 00:03:32.454
we have established in 1988

00:03:32.478 --> 00:03:35.118
the Intergovernmental Panel
on Climate Change,

00:03:35.878 --> 00:03:39.254
the Rio Earth Summit in 1992,

00:03:39.278 --> 00:03:43.318
then rolling on a few years,
in 2009 we had the Copenhagen Accord,

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:48.414
where it established avoiding
a two-degree temperature rise

00:03:48.438 --> 00:03:51.918
in keeping with the science
and on the basis of equity.

00:03:52.638 --> 00:03:56.574
And then in 2012, we had the Rio+20 event.

00:03:56.598 --> 00:03:59.414
And all the way through,
during all of these meetings

00:03:59.438 --> 00:04:00.998
and many others as well,

00:04:01.398 --> 00:04:03.598
emissions have continued to rise.

00:04:04.878 --> 00:04:10.094
And if we focus on our historical
emission trend in recent years,

00:04:10.118 --> 00:04:12.334
and we put that together
with our understanding

00:04:12.358 --> 00:04:14.838
of the direction of travel
in our global economy,

00:04:15.238 --> 00:04:16.974
then we are much more on track

00:04:16.998 --> 00:04:19.998
for a four-degree centigrade
global warming

00:04:20.398 --> 00:04:23.638
than we are for the two-degree centigrade.

00:04:24.358 --> 00:04:26.094
Now, let's just pause for a moment

00:04:26.118 --> 00:04:29.917
and think about this four-degree
global average temperature.

00:04:30.558 --> 00:04:33.718
Most of our planet
is actually made up of the sea.

00:04:34.518 --> 00:04:37.838
Now, because the sea has a greater
thermal inertia than the land,

00:04:38.518 --> 00:04:41.614
the average temperatures over land
are actually going to be higher

00:04:41.638 --> 00:04:43.158
than they are over the sea.

00:04:43.598 --> 00:04:47.214
The second thing is that we
as human beings don't experience

00:04:47.238 --> 00:04:48.798
global average temperatures.

00:04:49.158 --> 00:04:51.974
We experience hot days, cold days,

00:04:51.998 --> 00:04:54.918
rainy days, especially if you live
in Manchester like me.

00:04:55.758 --> 00:04:58.414
So now put yourself in a city center.

00:04:58.438 --> 00:05:00.014
Imagine somewhere in the world:

00:05:00.038 --> 00:05:03.414
Mumbai, Beijing, New York, London.

00:05:03.438 --> 00:05:06.638
It's the hottest day
that you've ever experienced.

00:05:06.998 --> 00:05:08.454
There's sun beating down,

00:05:08.478 --> 00:05:10.838
there's concrete and glass all around you.

00:05:11.598 --> 00:05:13.774
Now imagine that same day --

00:05:13.798 --> 00:05:18.398
but it's six, eight,
maybe 10 to 12 degrees warmer

00:05:18.718 --> 00:05:20.478
on that day during that heat wave.

00:05:20.878 --> 00:05:23.212
That's the kind of thing
we're going to experience

00:05:23.236 --> 00:05:27.276
under a four-degree global
average temperature scenario.

00:05:27.918 --> 00:05:29.694
And the problem with these extremes,

00:05:29.718 --> 00:05:31.534
and not just the temperature extremes,

00:05:31.558 --> 00:05:35.614
but also the extremes in terms of storms
and other climate impacts,

00:05:35.638 --> 00:05:40.118
is our infrastructure is just not set up
to deal with these sorts of events.

00:05:40.478 --> 00:05:42.374
So our roads and our rail networks

00:05:42.398 --> 00:05:44.574
have been designed to last for a long time

00:05:44.598 --> 00:05:47.254
and withstand only
certain amounts of impacts

00:05:47.278 --> 00:05:48.894
in different parts of the world.

00:05:48.918 --> 00:05:51.174
And this is going to be
extremely challenged.

00:05:51.198 --> 00:05:54.734
Our power stations
are expected to be cooled by water

00:05:54.758 --> 00:05:58.518
to a certain temperature
to remain effective and resilient.

00:05:58.838 --> 00:06:01.094
And our buildings
are designed to be comfortable

00:06:01.118 --> 00:06:03.334
within a particular temperature range.

00:06:03.358 --> 00:06:06.494
And this is all going to be
significantly challenged

00:06:06.518 --> 00:06:08.774
under a four-degree-type scenario.

00:06:08.798 --> 00:06:12.598
Our infrastructure has not been
designed to cope with this.

00:06:14.398 --> 00:06:18.254
So if we go back, also thinking
about four degrees,

00:06:18.278 --> 00:06:20.254
it's not just the direct impacts,

00:06:20.278 --> 00:06:22.278
but also some indirect impacts.

00:06:22.598 --> 00:06:25.478
So if we take food security, for example.

00:06:25.878 --> 00:06:27.718
Maize and wheat yields

00:06:28.118 --> 00:06:29.774
in some parts of the world

00:06:29.798 --> 00:06:32.758
are expected to be up to 40 percent lower

00:06:33.158 --> 00:06:35.174
under a four-degree scenario,

00:06:35.198 --> 00:06:37.798
rice up to 30 percent lower.

00:06:38.118 --> 00:06:41.638
This will be absolutely devastating
for global food security.

00:06:42.638 --> 00:06:45.574
So all in all, the kinds
of impacts anticipated

00:06:45.598 --> 00:06:48.358
under this four-degree centigrade scenario

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:53.638
are going to be incompatible
with global organized living.

00:06:55.798 --> 00:06:59.758
So back to our trajectories and our graphs
of four degrees and two degrees.

00:07:00.918 --> 00:07:04.358
Is it reasonable still
to focus on the two-degree path?

00:07:04.878 --> 00:07:07.694
There are quite a lot of my colleagues
and other scientists

00:07:07.718 --> 00:07:11.038
who would say that it's now too late
to avoid a two-degree warming.

00:07:11.815 --> 00:07:14.054
But I would just like
to draw on my own research

00:07:14.078 --> 00:07:17.134
on energy systems, on food systems,

00:07:17.158 --> 00:07:18.998
aviation and also shipping,

00:07:19.558 --> 00:07:23.614
just to say that I think there is still
a small fighting chance

00:07:23.638 --> 00:07:27.254
of avoiding this two-degree
dangerous climate change.

00:07:27.278 --> 00:07:29.659
But we really need
to get to grips with the numbers

00:07:29.683 --> 00:07:30.883
to work out how to do it.

00:07:31.798 --> 00:07:34.598
So if you focus in on this trajectory
and these graphs,

00:07:35.038 --> 00:07:38.014
the yellow circle there
highlights that the departure

00:07:38.038 --> 00:07:40.534
from the red four-degree pathway

00:07:40.558 --> 00:07:44.598
to the two-degree
green pathway is immediate.

00:07:44.998 --> 00:07:47.974
And that's because
of cumulative emissions,

00:07:47.998 --> 00:07:49.574
or the carbon budget.

00:07:49.598 --> 00:07:53.254
So in other words, because
of the lights and the projectors

00:07:53.278 --> 00:07:54.974
that are on in this room right now,

00:07:54.998 --> 00:07:56.951
the CO2 that is going into our atmosphere

00:07:56.975 --> 00:07:59.295
as a result of that
electricity consumption

00:07:59.638 --> 00:08:01.134
lasts a very long time.

00:08:01.158 --> 00:08:05.174
Some of it will be in our atmosphere
for a century, maybe much longer.

00:08:05.198 --> 00:08:08.918
It will accumulate, and greenhouse gases
tend to be cumulative.

00:08:09.718 --> 00:08:12.534
And that tells us something
about these trajectories.

00:08:12.558 --> 00:08:16.574
First of all, it tells us that it's
the area under these curves that matter,

00:08:16.598 --> 00:08:19.574
not where we reach
at a particular date in future.

00:08:19.598 --> 00:08:21.789
And that's important,
because it doesn't matter

00:08:21.813 --> 00:08:24.614
if we come up with some amazing
whiz-bang technology

00:08:24.638 --> 00:08:28.494
to sort out our energy problem
on the last day of 2049,

00:08:28.518 --> 00:08:30.814
just in the nick of time
to sort things out.

00:08:30.838 --> 00:08:33.958
Because in the meantime,
emissions will have accumulated.

00:08:34.678 --> 00:08:39.758
So if we continue on this red,
four-degree centigrade scenario pathway,

00:08:40.278 --> 00:08:42.174
the longer we continue on it,

00:08:42.198 --> 00:08:45.574
that will need to be
made up for in later years

00:08:45.598 --> 00:08:49.438
to keep the same carbon budget,
to keep the same area under the curve,

00:08:49.918 --> 00:08:54.014
which means that that trajectory,
the red one there, becomes steeper.

00:08:54.038 --> 00:08:57.774
So in other words, if we don't reduce
emissions in the short to medium term,

00:08:57.798 --> 00:09:01.518
then we'll have to make more significant
year-on-year emission reductions.

00:09:02.558 --> 00:09:05.718
We also know that we have
to decarbonize our energy system.

00:09:06.158 --> 00:09:10.054
But if we don't start to cut
emissions in the short to medium term,

00:09:10.078 --> 00:09:12.438
then we will have to do that even sooner.

00:09:13.038 --> 00:09:15.918
So this poses really big
challenges for us.

00:09:18.038 --> 00:09:21.158
The other thing it does is tells us
something about energy policy.

00:09:21.718 --> 00:09:25.654
If you live in a part of the world where
per capita emissions are already high,

00:09:25.678 --> 00:09:29.118
it points us towards
reducing energy demand.

00:09:29.758 --> 00:09:32.094
And that's because
with all the will in the world,

00:09:32.118 --> 00:09:34.654
the large-scale engineering infrastructure

00:09:34.678 --> 00:09:36.814
that we need to roll out rapidly

00:09:36.838 --> 00:09:39.934
to decarbonize the supply side
of our energy system

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:42.198
is just simply not going
to happen in time.

00:09:42.638 --> 00:09:45.094
So it doesn't matter
whether we choose nuclear power

00:09:45.118 --> 00:09:46.974
or carbon capture and storage,

00:09:46.998 --> 00:09:49.334
upscale our biofuel production,

00:09:49.358 --> 00:09:53.574
or go for a much bigger roll-out
of wind turbines and wave turbines.

00:09:53.598 --> 00:09:55.238
All of that will take time.

00:09:55.678 --> 00:09:58.214
So because it's the area
under the curve that matters,

00:09:58.238 --> 00:10:00.174
we need to focus on energy efficiency,

00:10:00.198 --> 00:10:04.718
but also on energy conservation --
in other words, using less energy.

00:10:05.158 --> 00:10:07.374
And if we do that, that also means

00:10:07.398 --> 00:10:11.038
that as we continue to roll out
the supply-side technology,

00:10:11.339 --> 00:10:14.054
we will have less of a job to do
if we've actually managed

00:10:14.078 --> 00:10:16.374
to reduce our energy consumption,

00:10:16.398 --> 00:10:20.878
because we will then need
less infrastructure on the supply side.

00:10:21.678 --> 00:10:24.254
Another issue that we really
need to grapple with

00:10:24.278 --> 00:10:27.478
is the issue of well-being and equity.

00:10:27.918 --> 00:10:32.678
There are many parts of the world where
the standard of living needs to rise.

00:10:33.398 --> 00:10:38.134
Bbut with energy systems
currently reliant on fossil fuel,

00:10:38.158 --> 00:10:40.718
as those economies grow
so will emissions.

00:10:41.278 --> 00:10:44.854
And now, if we're all constrained
by the same amount of carbon budget,

00:10:44.878 --> 00:10:48.414
that means that if some parts of
the world's emissions are needing to rise,

00:10:48.438 --> 00:10:52.118
then other parts of the world's
emissions need to reduce.

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:57.118
So that poses very significant challenges
for wealthy nations.

00:10:57.878 --> 00:11:00.318
Because according to our research,

00:11:00.663 --> 00:11:03.854
if you're in a country where per capita
emissions are really high --

00:11:03.878 --> 00:11:07.318
so North America, Europe, Australia --

00:11:07.838 --> 00:11:11.094
emissions reductions of the order
of 10 percent per year,

00:11:11.118 --> 00:11:15.174
and starting immediately,
will be required for a good chance

00:11:15.198 --> 00:11:17.278
of avoiding the two-degree target.

00:11:18.078 --> 00:11:19.854
Let me just put that into context.

00:11:19.878 --> 00:11:21.694
The economist Nicholas Stern

00:11:21.718 --> 00:11:24.934
said that emission reductions
of more than one percent per year

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:29.478
had only ever been associated
with economic recession or upheaval.

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:35.798
So this poses huge challenges
for the issue of economic growth,

00:11:37.318 --> 00:11:40.918
because if we have our
high carbon infrastructure in place,

00:11:41.238 --> 00:11:43.638
it means that if our economies grow,

00:11:43.998 --> 00:11:45.678
then so do our emissions.

00:11:46.198 --> 00:11:48.294
So I'd just like to take
a quote from a paper

00:11:48.318 --> 00:11:51.718
by myself and Kevin Anderson back in 2011

00:11:52.198 --> 00:11:57.438
where we said that to avoid the two-degree
framing of dangerous climate change,

00:11:57.958 --> 00:12:02.174
economic growth needs to be exchanged
at least temporarily

00:12:02.198 --> 00:12:06.598
for a period of planned austerity
in wealthy nations.

00:12:08.318 --> 00:12:11.358
This is a really difficult
message to take,

00:12:12.158 --> 00:12:16.918
because what it suggests is that
we really need to do things differently.

00:12:17.398 --> 00:12:21.398
This is not about just incremental change.

00:12:21.918 --> 00:12:26.214
This is about doing things differently,
about whole system change,

00:12:26.238 --> 00:12:29.934
and sometimes
it's about doing less things.

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:32.374
And this applies to all of us,

00:12:32.398 --> 00:12:34.558
whatever sphere of influence we have.

00:12:34.998 --> 00:12:38.094
So it could be from writing
to our local politician

00:12:38.118 --> 00:12:41.318
to talking to our boss at work
or being the boss at work,

00:12:41.638 --> 00:12:46.118
or talking with our friends and family,
or, quite simply, changing our lifestyles.

00:12:47.238 --> 00:12:50.398
Because we really need
to make significant change.

00:12:50.878 --> 00:12:55.094
At the moment, we're choosing
a four-degree scenario.

00:12:55.118 --> 00:12:58.454
If we really want to avoid
the two-degree scenario,

00:12:58.478 --> 00:13:02.054
there really is no time
like the present to act.

00:13:02.078 --> 00:13:03.294
Thank you.

00:13:03.318 --> 00:13:10.078
(Applause)

00:13:12.785 --> 00:13:15.214
Bruno Giussani: Alice,
basically what you're saying,

00:13:15.238 --> 00:13:18.694
the talk is, unless wealthy nations
start cutting 10 percent per year

00:13:18.718 --> 00:13:23.574
the emissions now, this year,
not in 2020 or '25,

00:13:23.598 --> 00:13:27.558
we are going to go straight
to the four-plus-degree scenario.

00:13:28.118 --> 00:13:31.854
I am wondering what's your take
on the cut by 70 percent for 2070.

00:13:31.878 --> 00:13:35.454
Alice Bows-Larkin: Yeah, it's just
nowhere near enough to avoid two degrees.

00:13:35.478 --> 00:13:36.962
One of the things that often --

00:13:36.986 --> 00:13:40.534
when there are these modeling studies
that look at what we need to do,

00:13:40.558 --> 00:13:45.054
is they tend to hugely overestimate
how quickly other countries in the world

00:13:45.078 --> 00:13:46.654
can start to reduce emissions.

00:13:46.678 --> 00:13:50.014
So they make kind of
heroic assumptions about that.

00:13:50.038 --> 00:13:52.800
The more we do that,
because it's the cumulative emissions,

00:13:52.824 --> 00:13:54.782
the short-term stuff that really matters.

00:13:54.790 --> 00:13:56.425
So it does make a huge difference.

00:13:56.449 --> 00:13:58.414
If a big country like China, for example,

00:13:58.438 --> 00:14:00.854
continues to grow
even for just a few extra years,

00:14:00.878 --> 00:14:03.894
that will make a big difference
to when we need to decarbonize.

00:14:03.918 --> 00:14:06.414
So I don't think we can even say
when it will be,

00:14:06.438 --> 00:14:09.398
because it all depends
on what we have to do in the short term.

00:14:09.422 --> 00:14:12.694
But I think we've just got huge scope,
and we don't pull those levers

00:14:12.718 --> 00:14:15.638
that allow us to reduce
the energy demand, which is a shame.

00:14:15.956 --> 00:14:18.814
BG: Alice, thank you for coming
to TED and sharing this data.

00:14:18.838 --> 00:14:20.038
ABL: Thank you.

00:14:20.078 --> 00:14:21.958
(Applause)

title: Soon we'll cure diseases with a cell, not a pill
transcript: I want to talk to you about the future of medicine. But before I do that, I want to talk a little bit about the past. Now, throughout much of the recent history of medicine, we've thought about illness and treatment in terms of a profoundly simple model. In fact, the model is so simple that you could summarize it in six words: have disease, take pill, kill something.Now, the reason for the dominance of this model is of course the antibiotic revolution. Many of you might not know this, but we happen to be celebrating the hundredth year of the introduction of antibiotics into the United States. But what you do know is that that introduction was nothing short of transformative. Here you had a chemical, either from the natural world or artificially synthesized in the laboratory, and it would course through your body, it would find its target, lock into its target — a microbe or some part of a microbe — and then turn off a lock and a key with exquisite deftness, exquisite specificity. And you would end up taking a previously fatal, lethal disease — a pneumonia, syphilis, tuberculosis — and transforming that into a curable, or treatable illness. You have a pneumonia, you take penicillin, you kill the microbe and you cure the disease.So seductive was this idea, so potent the metaphor of lock and key and killing something, that it really swept through biology. It was a transformation like no other. And we've really spent the last 100 years trying to replicate that model over and over again in noninfectious diseases, in chronic diseases like diabetes and hypertension and heart disease. And it's worked, but it's only worked partly. Let me show you. You know, if you take the entire universe of all chemical reactions in the human body, every chemical reaction that your body is capable of, most people think that that number is on the order of a million. Let's call it a million. And now you ask the question, what number or fraction of reactions can actually be targeted by the entire pharmacopoeia, all of medicinal chemistry? That number is 250. The rest is chemical darkness. In other words, 0.025 percent of all chemical reactions in your body are actually targetable by this lock and key mechanism. You know, if you think about human physiology as a vast global telephone network with interacting nodes and interacting pieces, then all of our medicinal chemistry is operating on one tiny corner at the edge, the outer edge, of that network. It's like all of our pharmaceutical chemistry is a pole operator in Wichita, Kansas who is tinkering with about 10 or 15 telephone lines.So what do we do about this idea? What if we reorganized this approach? In fact, it turns out that the natural world gives us a sense of how one might think about illness in a radically different way, rather than disease, medicine, target. In fact, the natural world is organized hierarchically upwards, not downwards, but upwards, and we begin with a self-regulating, semi-autonomous unit called a cell. These self-regulating, semi-autonomous units give rise to self-regulating, semi-autonomous units called organs, and these organs coalesce to form things called humans, and these organisms ultimately live in environments, which are partly self-regulating and partly semi-autonomous.What's nice about this scheme, this hierarchical scheme building upwards rather than downwards, is that it allows us to think about illness as well in a somewhat different way. Take a disease like cancer. Since the 1950s, we've tried rather desperately to apply this lock and key model to cancer. We've tried to kill cells using a variety of chemotherapies  or targeted therapies, and as most of us know, that's worked. It's worked for diseases like leukemia. It's worked for some forms of breast cancer, but eventually you run to the ceiling of that approach. And it's only in the last 10 years or so that we've begun to think about using the immune system, remembering that in fact the cancer cell doesn't grow in a vacuum. It actually grows in a human organism. And could you use the organismal capacity, the fact that human beings have an immune system, to attack cancer? In fact, it's led to the some of the most spectacular new medicines in cancer.And finally there's the level of the environment, isn't there? You know, we don't think of cancer as altering the environment. But let me give you an example of a profoundly carcinogenic environment. It's called a prison. You take loneliness, you take depression, you take confinement, and you add to that, rolled up in a little white sheet of paper, one of the most potent neurostimulants that we know, called nicotine, and you add to that one of the most potent addictive substances that you know, and you have a pro-carcinogenic environment. But you can have anti-carcinogenic environments too. There are attempts to create milieus, change the hormonal milieu for breast cancer, for instance. We're trying to change the metabolic milieu for other forms of cancer.Or take another disease, like depression. Again, working upwards, since the 1960s and 1970s, we've tried, again, desperately to turn off molecules that operate between nerve cells — serotonin, dopamine — and tried to cure depression that way, and that's worked, but then that reached the limit. And we now know that what you really probably need to do is to change the physiology of the organ, the brain, rewire it, remodel it, and that, of course, we know study upon study has shown that talk therapy does exactly that, and study upon study has shown that talk therapy combined with medicines, pills, really is much more effective than either one alone. Can we imagine a more immersive environment that will change depression? Can you lock out the signals that elicit depression? Again, moving upwards along this hierarchical chain of organization. What's really at stake perhaps here is not the medicine itself but a metaphor. Rather than killing something, in the case of the great chronic degenerative diseases — kidney failure, diabetes, hypertension, osteoarthritis — maybe what we really need to do is change the metaphor to growing something. And that's the key, perhaps, to reframing our thinking about medicine.Now, this idea of changing, of creating a perceptual shift, as it were, came home to me to roost in a very personal manner about 10 years ago. About 10 years ago — I've been a runner most of my life — I went for a run, a Saturday morning run, I came back and woke up and I basically couldn't move. My right knee was swollen up, and you could hear that ominous crunch of bone against bone. And one of the perks of being a physician is that you get to order your own MRIs. And I had an MRI the next week, and it looked like that. Essentially, the meniscus of cartilage that is between bone had been completely torn and the bone itself had been shattered.Now, if you're looking at me and feeling sorry, let me tell you a few facts. If I was to take an MRI of every person in this audience, 60 percent of you would show signs of bone degeneration and cartilage degeneration like this. 85 percent of all women by the age of 70 would show moderate to severe cartilage degeneration. 50 to 60 percent of the men in this audience would also have such signs. So this is a very common disease. Well, the second perk of being a physician is that you can get to experiment on your own ailments. So about 10 years ago we began, we brought this process into the laboratory, and we began to do simple experiments, mechanically trying to fix this degeneration. We tried to inject chemicals into the knee spaces of animals to try to reverse cartilage degeneration, and to put a short summary on a very long and painful process, essentially it came to naught. Nothing happened. And then about seven years ago, we had a research student from Australia. The nice thing about Australians is that they're habitually used to looking at the world upside down.(Laughter)And so Dan suggested to me, "You know, maybe it isn't a mechanical problem. Maybe it isn't a chemical problem. Maybe it's a stem cell problem." In other words, he had two hypotheses. Number one, there is such a thing as a skeletal stem cell — a skeletal stem cell that builds up the entire vertebrate skeleton, bone, cartilage and the fibrous elements of skeleton, just like there's a stem cell in blood, just like there's a stem cell in the nervous system. And two, that maybe that, the degeneration or dysfunction of this stem cell is what's causing osteochondral arthritis, a very common ailment. So really the question was, were we looking for a pill when we should have really been looking for a cell. So we switched our models, and now we began to look for skeletal stem cells. And to cut again a long story short, about five years ago, we found these cells. They live inside the skeleton. Here's a schematic and then a real photograph of one of them. The white stuff is bone, and these red columns that you see and the yellow cells are cells that have arisen from one single skeletal stem cell — columns of cartilage, columns of bone coming out of a single cell. These cells are fascinating. They have four properties. Number one is that they live where they're expected to live. They live just underneath the surface of the bone, underneath cartilage. You know, in biology, it's location, location, location. And they move into the appropriate areas and form bone and cartilage. That's one. Here's an interesting property. You can take them out of the vertebrate skeleton, you can culture them in petri dishes in the laboratory, and they are dying to form cartilage. Remember how we couldn't form cartilage for love or money? These cells are dying to form cartilage. They form their own furls of cartilage around themselves. They're also, number three, the most efficient repairers of fractures that we've ever encountered. This is a little bone, a mouse bone that we fractured and then let it heal by itself. These stem cells have come in and repaired, in yellow, the bone, in white, the cartilage, almost completely. So much so that if you label them with a fluorescent dye you can see them like some kind of peculiar cellular glue coming into the area of a fracture, fixing it locally and then stopping their work. Now, the fourth one is the most ominous, and that is that their numbers decline precipitously, precipitously, tenfold, fiftyfold, as you age.And so what had happened, really, is that we found ourselves in a perceptual shift. We had gone hunting for pills but we ended up finding theories. And in some ways we had hooked ourselves back onto this idea: cells, organisms, environments, because we were now thinking about bone stem cells, we were thinking about arthritis in terms of a cellular disease.And then the next question was, are there organs? Can you build this as an organ outside the body? Can you implant cartilage into areas of trauma? And perhaps most interestingly, can you ascend right up and create environments? You know, we know that exercise remodels bone, but come on, none of us is going to exercise. So could you imagine ways of passively loading and unloading bone so that you can recreate or regenerate degenerating cartilage?And perhaps more interesting, and more importantly, the question is, can you apply this model more globally outside medicine? What's at stake, as I said before, is not killing something, but growing something. And it raises a series of, I think, some of the most interesting questions about how we think about medicine in the future. Could your medicine be a cell and not a pill? How would we grow these cells? What we would we do to stop the malignant growth of these cells? We heard about the problems of unleashing growth. Could we implant suicide genes into these cells to stop them from growing? Could your medicine be an organ that's created outside the body and then implanted into the body? Could that stop some of the degeneration? What if the organ needed to have memory? In cases of diseases of the nervous system some of those organs had memory. How could we implant those memories back in? Could we store these organs? Would each organ have to be developed for an individual human being and put back? And perhaps most puzzlingly, could your medicine be an environment? Could you patent an environment? You know, in every culture, shamans have been using environments as medicines. Could we imagine that for our future? I've talked a lot about models. I began this talk with models. So let me end with some thoughts about model building. That's what we do as scientists. You know, when an architect builds a model, he or she is trying to show you a world in miniature. But when a scientist is building a model, he or she is trying to show you the world in metaphor. He or she is trying to create a new way of seeing. The former is a scale shift. The latter is a perceptual shift.Now, antibiotics created such a perceptual shift in our way of thinking about medicine that it really colored, distorted, very successfully, the way we've thought about medicine for the last hundred years. But we need new models to think about medicine in the future. That's what's at stake.You know, there's a popular trope out there that the reason we haven't had the transformative impact on the treatment of illness is because we don't have powerful-enough drugs, and that's partly true. But perhaps the real reason is that we don't have powerful-enough ways of thinking about medicines. It's certainly true that it would be lovely to have new medicines. But perhaps what's really at stake are three more intangible M's: mechanisms, models, metaphors.Thank you.(Applause)Chris Anderson: I really like this metaphor. How does it link in? There's a lot of talk in technologyland about the personalization of medicine, that we have all this data and that medical treatments of the future will be for you specifically, your genome, your current context. Does that apply to this model you've got here?Siddhartha Mukherjee: It's a very interesting question. We've thought about personalization of medicine very much in terms of genomics. That's because the gene is such a dominant metaphor, again, to use that same word, in medicine today, that we think the genome will drive the personalization of medicine. But of course the genome is just the bottom of a long chain of being, as it were. That chain of being, really the first organized unit of that, is the cell. So, if we are really going to deliver in medicine in this way, we have to think of personalizing cellular therapies, and then personalizing organ or organismal therapies, and ultimately personalizing immersion therapies for the environment. So I think at every stage, you know — there's that metaphor, there's turtles all the way. Well, in this, there's personalization all the way.CA: So when you say medicine could be a cell and not a pill, you're talking about potentially your own cells.SM: Absolutely. CA: So converted to stem cells, perhaps tested against all kinds of drugs or something, and prepared.SM: And there's no perhaps. This is what we're doing. This is what's happening, and in fact, we're slowly moving, not away from genomics, but incorporating genomics into what we call multi-order, semi-autonomous, self-regulating systems, like cells, like organs, like environments.CA: Thank you so much.SM: Pleasure. Thanks.
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.718 --> 00:00:16.894
I want to talk to you
about the future of medicine.

00:00:16.918 --> 00:00:21.014
But before I do that, I want to talk
a little bit about the past.

00:00:21.038 --> 00:00:24.654
Now, throughout much
of the recent history of medicine,

00:00:24.678 --> 00:00:28.494
we've thought about illness and treatment

00:00:28.518 --> 00:00:31.894
in terms of a profoundly simple model.

00:00:31.918 --> 00:00:34.614
In fact, the model is so simple

00:00:34.638 --> 00:00:37.694
that you could summarize it in six words:

00:00:37.718 --> 00:00:41.798
have disease, take pill, kill something.

00:00:43.038 --> 00:00:47.774
Now, the reason
for the dominance of this model

00:00:47.798 --> 00:00:50.414
is of course the antibiotic revolution.

00:00:50.438 --> 00:00:53.614
Many of you might not know this,
but we happen to be celebrating

00:00:53.638 --> 00:00:57.694
the hundredth year of the introduction
of antibiotics into the United States.

00:00:57.718 --> 00:00:59.334
But what you do know

00:00:59.358 --> 00:01:03.598
is that that introduction
was nothing short of transformative.

00:01:04.838 --> 00:01:08.694
Here you had a chemical,
either from the natural world

00:01:08.718 --> 00:01:11.454
or artificially synthesized
in the laboratory,

00:01:11.478 --> 00:01:14.734
and it would course through your body,

00:01:14.758 --> 00:01:17.534
it would find its target,

00:01:17.558 --> 00:01:19.214
lock into its target --

00:01:19.238 --> 00:01:21.454
a microbe or some part of a microbe --

00:01:21.478 --> 00:01:24.918
and then turn off a lock and a key

00:01:25.918 --> 00:01:29.454
with exquisite deftness,
exquisite specificity.

00:01:29.478 --> 00:01:33.774
And you would end up taking
a previously fatal, lethal disease --

00:01:33.798 --> 00:01:36.934
a pneumonia, syphilis, tuberculosis --

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:40.998
and transforming that
into a curable, or treatable illness.

00:01:42.038 --> 00:01:43.518
You have a pneumonia,

00:01:44.438 --> 00:01:45.814
you take penicillin,

00:01:45.838 --> 00:01:47.374
you kill the microbe

00:01:47.398 --> 00:01:49.534
and you cure the disease.

00:01:49.558 --> 00:01:52.494
So seductive was this idea,

00:01:52.518 --> 00:01:56.694
so potent the metaphor of lock and key

00:01:56.718 --> 00:01:58.254
and killing something,

00:01:58.278 --> 00:02:00.294
that it really swept through biology.

00:02:00.318 --> 00:02:02.438
It was a transformation like no other.

00:02:04.118 --> 00:02:07.294
And we've really spent the last 100 years

00:02:07.318 --> 00:02:10.774
trying to replicate that model
over and over again

00:02:10.798 --> 00:02:12.037
in noninfectious diseases,

00:02:12.061 --> 00:02:16.181
in chronic diseases like diabetes
and hypertension and heart disease.

00:02:17.078 --> 00:02:20.717
And it's worked,
but it's only worked partly.

00:02:21.078 --> 00:02:22.734
Let me show you.

00:02:22.758 --> 00:02:25.654
You know, if you take the entire universe

00:02:25.678 --> 00:02:29.174
of all chemical reactions
in the human body,

00:02:29.198 --> 00:02:32.494
every chemical reaction
that your body is capable of,

00:02:32.518 --> 00:02:35.534
most people think that that number
is on the order of a million.

00:02:35.558 --> 00:02:36.854
Let's call it a million.

00:02:36.878 --> 00:02:38.574
And now you ask the question,

00:02:38.598 --> 00:02:41.254
what number or fraction of reactions

00:02:41.278 --> 00:02:43.094
can actually be targeted

00:02:43.118 --> 00:02:47.934
by the entire pharmacopoeia,
all of medicinal chemistry?

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:49.998
That number is 250.

00:02:51.638 --> 00:02:54.174
The rest is chemical darkness.

00:02:54.198 --> 00:03:00.374
In other words, 0.025 percent
of all chemical reactions in your body

00:03:00.398 --> 00:03:04.518
are actually targetable
by this lock and key mechanism.

00:03:05.638 --> 00:03:08.694
You know, if you think
about human physiology

00:03:08.718 --> 00:03:12.174
as a vast global telephone network

00:03:12.198 --> 00:03:16.078
with interacting nodes
and interacting pieces,

00:03:16.558 --> 00:03:19.734
then all of our medicinal chemistry

00:03:19.758 --> 00:03:22.014
is operating on one tiny corner

00:03:22.038 --> 00:03:24.734
at the edge, the outer edge,
of that network.

00:03:24.758 --> 00:03:28.574
It's like all of our
pharmaceutical chemistry

00:03:28.598 --> 00:03:32.374
is a pole operator in Wichita, Kansas

00:03:32.398 --> 00:03:35.358
who is tinkering with about
10 or 15 telephone lines.

00:03:36.838 --> 00:03:38.998
So what do we do about this idea?

00:03:40.118 --> 00:03:42.478
What if we reorganized this approach?

00:03:44.038 --> 00:03:47.414
In fact, it turns out
that the natural world

00:03:47.438 --> 00:03:52.494
gives us a sense of how one
might think about illness

00:03:52.518 --> 00:03:54.174
in a radically different way,

00:03:54.198 --> 00:03:57.918
rather than disease, medicine, target.

00:03:59.038 --> 00:04:02.414
In fact, the natural world
is organized hierarchically upwards,

00:04:02.438 --> 00:04:04.294
not downwards, but upwards,

00:04:04.318 --> 00:04:10.558
and we begin with a self-regulating,
semi-autonomous unit called a cell.

00:04:11.598 --> 00:04:14.814
These self-regulating,
semi-autonomous units

00:04:14.838 --> 00:04:19.654
give rise to self-regulating,
semi-autonomous units called organs,

00:04:19.678 --> 00:04:22.678
and these organs coalesce
to form things called humans,

00:04:23.878 --> 00:04:27.774
and these organisms
ultimately live in environments,

00:04:27.798 --> 00:04:31.398
which are partly self-regulating
and partly semi-autonomous.

00:04:32.878 --> 00:04:35.694
What's nice about this scheme,
this hierarchical scheme

00:04:35.718 --> 00:04:38.414
building upwards rather than downwards,

00:04:38.438 --> 00:04:41.814
is that it allows us
to think about illness as well

00:04:41.838 --> 00:04:43.172
in a somewhat different way.

00:04:44.358 --> 00:04:46.478
Take a disease like cancer.

00:04:48.078 --> 00:04:49.374
Since the 1950s,

00:04:49.398 --> 00:04:54.925
we've tried rather desperately to apply
this lock and key model to cancer.

00:04:54.949 --> 00:04:57.838
We've tried to kill cells

00:04:57.863 --> 00:05:02.210
using a variety of chemotherapies 
or targeted therapies,

00:05:02.234 --> 00:05:04.654
and as most of us know, that's worked.

00:05:04.678 --> 00:05:06.536
It's worked for diseases like leukemia.

00:05:06.560 --> 00:05:08.934
It's worked for some forms
of breast cancer,

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:12.694
but eventually you run
to the ceiling of that approach.

00:05:12.718 --> 00:05:15.214
And it's only in the last 10 years or so

00:05:15.238 --> 00:05:18.374
that we've begun to think
about using the immune system,

00:05:18.398 --> 00:05:21.494
remembering that in fact the cancer cell
doesn't grow in a vacuum.

00:05:21.518 --> 00:05:23.574
It actually grows in a human organism.

00:05:23.598 --> 00:05:25.894
And could you use the organismal capacity,

00:05:25.918 --> 00:05:29.061
the fact that human beings
have an immune system, to attack cancer?

00:05:29.085 --> 00:05:33.285
In fact, it's led to the some of the most
spectacular new medicines in cancer.

00:05:34.438 --> 00:05:37.772
And finally there's the level
of the environment, isn't there?

00:05:38.118 --> 00:05:41.094
You know, we don't think of cancer
as altering the environment.

00:05:41.118 --> 00:05:46.014
But let me give you an example
of a profoundly carcinogenic environment.

00:05:46.038 --> 00:05:47.238
It's called a prison.

00:05:48.118 --> 00:05:53.254
You take loneliness, you take depression,
you take confinement,

00:05:53.278 --> 00:05:54.478
and you add to that,

00:05:55.358 --> 00:05:57.918
rolled up in a little
white sheet of paper,

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:02.734
one of the most potent neurostimulants
that we know, called nicotine,

00:06:02.758 --> 00:06:07.694
and you add to that one of the most potent
addictive substances that you know,

00:06:07.718 --> 00:06:10.514
and you have
a pro-carcinogenic environment.

00:06:11.478 --> 00:06:13.934
But you can have anti-carcinogenic
environments too.

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:16.654
There are attempts to create milieus,

00:06:16.678 --> 00:06:19.440
change the hormonal milieu
for breast cancer, for instance.

00:06:20.398 --> 00:06:23.814
We're trying to change the metabolic
milieu for other forms of cancer.

00:06:23.838 --> 00:06:26.254
Or take another disease, like depression.

00:06:26.278 --> 00:06:28.934
Again, working upwards,

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:32.974
since the 1960s and 1970s,
we've tried, again, desperately

00:06:32.998 --> 00:06:37.174
to turn off molecules
that operate between nerve cells --

00:06:37.198 --> 00:06:39.374
serotonin, dopamine --

00:06:39.398 --> 00:06:41.214
and tried to cure depression that way,

00:06:41.238 --> 00:06:43.678
and that's worked,
but then that reached the limit.

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:47.578
And we now know that what you
really probably need to do

00:06:47.602 --> 00:06:50.574
is to change the physiology
of the organ, the brain,

00:06:50.598 --> 00:06:52.734
rewire it, remodel it,

00:06:52.758 --> 00:06:55.334
and that, of course,
we know study upon study has shown

00:06:55.358 --> 00:06:57.073
that talk therapy does exactly that,

00:06:57.097 --> 00:06:59.353
and study upon study
has shown that talk therapy

00:06:59.377 --> 00:07:02.494
combined with medicines, pills,

00:07:02.518 --> 00:07:04.947
really is much more effective
than either one alone.

00:07:05.798 --> 00:07:09.374
Can we imagine a more immersive
environment that will change depression?

00:07:09.398 --> 00:07:13.454
Can you lock out the signals
that elicit depression?

00:07:13.478 --> 00:07:18.958
Again, moving upwards along this
hierarchical chain of organization.

00:07:19.718 --> 00:07:22.414
What's really at stake perhaps here

00:07:22.438 --> 00:07:25.694
is not the medicine itself but a metaphor.

00:07:25.718 --> 00:07:27.774
Rather than killing something,

00:07:27.798 --> 00:07:31.494
in the case of the great
chronic degenerative diseases --

00:07:31.518 --> 00:07:35.014
kidney failure, diabetes,
hypertension, osteoarthritis --

00:07:35.038 --> 00:07:38.610
maybe what we really need to do is change
the metaphor to growing something.

00:07:38.634 --> 00:07:40.574
And that's the key, perhaps,

00:07:40.598 --> 00:07:43.094
to reframing our thinking about medicine.

00:07:43.118 --> 00:07:46.574
Now, this idea of changing,

00:07:46.598 --> 00:07:48.934
of creating a perceptual
shift, as it were,

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:52.254
came home to me to roost in a very
personal manner about 10 years ago.

00:07:52.278 --> 00:07:55.054
About 10 years ago --
I've been a runner most of my life --

00:07:55.078 --> 00:07:57.054
I went for a run, a Saturday morning run,

00:07:57.078 --> 00:07:59.734
I came back and woke up
and I basically couldn't move.

00:07:59.758 --> 00:08:01.774
My right knee was swollen up,

00:08:01.798 --> 00:08:05.318
and you could hear that ominous crunch
of bone against bone.

00:08:06.198 --> 00:08:11.094
And one of the perks of being a physician
is that you get to order your own MRIs.

00:08:11.118 --> 00:08:15.094
And I had an MRI the next week,
and it looked like that.

00:08:15.118 --> 00:08:19.414
Essentially, the meniscus of cartilage
that is between bone

00:08:19.438 --> 00:08:22.854
had been completely torn
and the bone itself had been shattered.

00:08:22.878 --> 00:08:25.334
Now, if you're looking at me
and feeling sorry,

00:08:25.358 --> 00:08:27.174
let me tell you a few facts.

00:08:27.198 --> 00:08:31.374
If I was to take an MRI
of every person in this audience,

00:08:31.398 --> 00:08:33.454
60 percent of you would show signs

00:08:33.478 --> 00:08:36.254
of bone degeneration
and cartilage degeneration like this.

00:08:36.278 --> 00:08:40.054
85 percent of all women by the age of 70

00:08:40.078 --> 00:08:43.334
would show moderate to severe
cartilage degeneration.

00:08:43.358 --> 00:08:45.654
50 to 60 percent
of the men in this audience

00:08:45.678 --> 00:08:47.014
would also have such signs.

00:08:47.038 --> 00:08:48.814
So this is a very common disease.

00:08:48.838 --> 00:08:50.934
Well, the second perk of being a physician

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:54.093
is that you can get
to experiment on your own ailments.

00:08:54.117 --> 00:08:56.334
So about 10 years ago we began,

00:08:56.358 --> 00:08:58.774
we brought this process
into the laboratory,

00:08:58.798 --> 00:09:00.814
and we began to do simple experiments,

00:09:00.838 --> 00:09:03.294
mechanically trying
to fix this degeneration.

00:09:03.318 --> 00:09:08.134
We tried to inject chemicals
into the knee spaces of animals

00:09:08.158 --> 00:09:10.814
to try to reverse cartilage degeneration,

00:09:10.838 --> 00:09:15.374
and to put a short summary
on a very long and painful process,

00:09:15.398 --> 00:09:17.174
essentially it came to naught.

00:09:17.198 --> 00:09:18.398
Nothing happened.

00:09:18.838 --> 00:09:23.614
And then about seven years ago,
we had a research student from Australia.

00:09:23.638 --> 00:09:25.163
The nice thing about Australians

00:09:25.163 --> 00:09:28.479
is that they're habitually used to
looking at the world upside down.

00:09:28.504 --> 00:09:29.661
(Laughter)

00:09:29.685 --> 00:09:33.774
And so Dan suggested to me, "You know,
maybe it isn't a mechanical problem.

00:09:33.798 --> 00:09:37.798
Maybe it isn't a chemical problem.
Maybe it's a stem cell problem."

00:09:39.718 --> 00:09:41.614
In other words, he had two hypotheses.

00:09:41.638 --> 00:09:45.454
Number one, there is such a thing
as a skeletal stem cell --

00:09:45.478 --> 00:09:48.998
a skeletal stem cell that builds up
the entire vertebrate skeleton,

00:09:49.022 --> 00:09:51.554
bone, cartilage and the fibrous
elements of skeleton,

00:09:51.578 --> 00:09:53.443
just like there's a stem cell in blood,

00:09:53.468 --> 00:09:55.903
just like there's a stem cell
in the nervous system.

00:09:55.927 --> 00:09:59.487
And two, that maybe that, the degeneration
or dysfunction of this stem cell

00:09:59.512 --> 00:10:03.014
is what's causing osteochondral arthritis,
a very common ailment.

00:10:03.038 --> 00:10:06.254
So really the question was,
were we looking for a pill

00:10:06.278 --> 00:10:08.894
when we should have really
been looking for a cell.

00:10:08.918 --> 00:10:11.774
So we switched our models,

00:10:11.798 --> 00:10:14.918
and now we began
to look for skeletal stem cells.

00:10:15.518 --> 00:10:18.014
And to cut again a long story short,

00:10:18.038 --> 00:10:20.958
about five years ago,
we found these cells.

00:10:21.758 --> 00:10:24.254
They live inside the skeleton.

00:10:24.278 --> 00:10:27.174
Here's a schematic and then
a real photograph of one of them.

00:10:27.198 --> 00:10:29.134
The white stuff is bone,

00:10:29.158 --> 00:10:32.174
and these red columns that you see
and the yellow cells

00:10:32.198 --> 00:10:35.454
are cells that have arisen
from one single skeletal stem cell --

00:10:35.478 --> 00:10:38.774
columns of cartilage, columns of bone
coming out of a single cell.

00:10:38.798 --> 00:10:42.094
These cells are fascinating.
They have four properties.

00:10:42.118 --> 00:10:45.894
Number one is that they live
where they're expected to live.

00:10:45.918 --> 00:10:48.294
They live just underneath
the surface of the bone,

00:10:48.318 --> 00:10:49.854
underneath cartilage.

00:10:49.878 --> 00:10:52.498
You know, in biology,
it's location, location, location.

00:10:52.522 --> 00:10:56.774
And they move into the appropriate areas
and form bone and cartilage.

00:10:56.798 --> 00:10:58.054
That's one.

00:10:58.078 --> 00:10:59.614
Here's an interesting property.

00:10:59.638 --> 00:11:02.294
You can take them out
of the vertebrate skeleton,

00:11:02.318 --> 00:11:04.894
you can culture them
in petri dishes in the laboratory,

00:11:04.918 --> 00:11:06.894
and they are dying to form cartilage.

00:11:06.918 --> 00:11:09.640
Remember how we couldn't
form cartilage for love or money?

00:11:09.664 --> 00:11:11.583
These cells are dying to form cartilage.

00:11:11.608 --> 00:11:14.613
They form their own furls
of cartilage around themselves.

00:11:14.638 --> 00:11:16.254
They're also, number three,

00:11:16.278 --> 00:11:20.454
the most efficient repairers
of fractures that we've ever encountered.

00:11:20.478 --> 00:11:23.774
This is a little bone,
a mouse bone that we fractured

00:11:23.798 --> 00:11:25.334
and then let it heal by itself.

00:11:25.358 --> 00:11:28.374
These stem cells have come in
and repaired, in yellow, the bone,

00:11:28.398 --> 00:11:31.014
in white, the cartilage,
almost completely.

00:11:31.038 --> 00:11:34.574
So much so that if you label them
with a fluorescent dye

00:11:34.598 --> 00:11:38.334
you can see them like some kind
of peculiar cellular glue

00:11:38.358 --> 00:11:40.214
coming into the area of a fracture,

00:11:40.238 --> 00:11:43.214
fixing it locally
and then stopping their work.

00:11:43.238 --> 00:11:45.574
Now, the fourth one is the most ominous,

00:11:45.598 --> 00:11:49.734
and that is that their numbers
decline precipitously,

00:11:49.758 --> 00:11:54.454
precipitously, tenfold,
fiftyfold, as you age.

00:11:54.478 --> 00:11:56.054
And so what had happened, really,

00:11:56.078 --> 00:11:58.934
is that we found ourselves
in a perceptual shift.

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:01.694
We had gone hunting for pills

00:12:01.718 --> 00:12:04.214
but we ended up finding theories.

00:12:04.238 --> 00:12:05.454
And in some ways

00:12:05.478 --> 00:12:08.094
we had hooked ourselves
back onto this idea:

00:12:08.118 --> 00:12:11.014
cells, organisms, environments,

00:12:11.038 --> 00:12:13.614
because we were now thinking
about bone stem cells,

00:12:13.638 --> 00:12:17.078
we were thinking about arthritis
in terms of a cellular disease.

00:12:17.798 --> 00:12:20.084
And then the next question was,
are there organs?

00:12:20.108 --> 00:12:22.347
Can you build this
as an organ outside the body?

00:12:22.371 --> 00:12:26.214
Can you implant cartilage
into areas of trauma?

00:12:26.238 --> 00:12:28.214
And perhaps most interestingly,

00:12:28.238 --> 00:12:30.614
can you ascend right up
and create environments?

00:12:30.638 --> 00:12:33.694
You know, we know
that exercise remodels bone,

00:12:33.718 --> 00:12:36.134
but come on, none of us
is going to exercise.

00:12:36.158 --> 00:12:41.334
So could you imagine ways of passively
loading and unloading bone

00:12:41.358 --> 00:12:46.174
so that you can recreate
or regenerate degenerating cartilage?

00:12:46.198 --> 00:12:48.579
And perhaps more interesting,
and more importantly,

00:12:48.603 --> 00:12:52.054
the question is, can you apply this model
more globally outside medicine?

00:12:52.078 --> 00:12:56.134
What's at stake, as I said before,
is not killing something,

00:12:56.158 --> 00:12:57.598
but growing something.

00:12:58.238 --> 00:13:03.054
And it raises a series of, I think,
some of the most interesting questions

00:13:03.078 --> 00:13:05.598
about how we think
about medicine in the future.

00:13:06.998 --> 00:13:09.878
Could your medicine
be a cell and not a pill?

00:13:10.798 --> 00:13:13.174
How would we grow these cells?

00:13:13.198 --> 00:13:16.214
What we would we do to stop
the malignant growth of these cells?

00:13:16.238 --> 00:13:20.134
We heard about the problems
of unleashing growth.

00:13:20.158 --> 00:13:22.934
Could we implant
suicide genes into these cells

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.398
to stop them from growing?

00:13:24.998 --> 00:13:28.934
Could your medicine be an organ
that's created outside the body

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:30.894
and then implanted into the body?

00:13:30.918 --> 00:13:33.654
Could that stop some of the degeneration?

00:13:33.678 --> 00:13:35.583
What if the organ needed to have memory?

00:13:35.607 --> 00:13:40.374
In cases of diseases of the nervous system
some of those organs had memory.

00:13:40.398 --> 00:13:42.854
How could we implant
those memories back in?

00:13:42.878 --> 00:13:44.694
Could we store these organs?

00:13:44.718 --> 00:13:47.861
Would each organ have to be developed
for an individual human being

00:13:47.885 --> 00:13:49.085
and put back?

00:13:50.478 --> 00:13:53.094
And perhaps most puzzlingly,

00:13:53.118 --> 00:13:54.928
could your medicine be an environment?

00:13:56.118 --> 00:13:57.774
Could you patent an environment?

00:13:57.798 --> 00:14:01.254
You know, in every culture,

00:14:01.278 --> 00:14:04.214
shamans have been using
environments as medicines.

00:14:04.238 --> 00:14:06.558
Could we imagine that for our future?

00:14:08.038 --> 00:14:11.414
I've talked a lot about models.
I began this talk with models.

00:14:11.438 --> 00:14:14.134
So let me end with some thoughts
about model building.

00:14:14.158 --> 00:14:16.254
That's what we do as scientists.

00:14:16.278 --> 00:14:19.574
You know, when an architect
builds a model,

00:14:19.598 --> 00:14:22.894
he or she is trying to show you
a world in miniature.

00:14:22.918 --> 00:14:25.814
But when a scientist is building a model,

00:14:25.838 --> 00:14:28.362
he or she is trying to show you
the world in metaphor.

00:14:29.558 --> 00:14:33.414
He or she is trying to create
a new way of seeing.

00:14:33.438 --> 00:14:37.558
The former is a scale shift.
The latter is a perceptual shift.

00:14:38.878 --> 00:14:43.814
Now, antibiotics created
such a perceptual shift

00:14:43.838 --> 00:14:47.654
in our way of thinking about medicine
that it really colored, distorted,

00:14:47.678 --> 00:14:51.598
very successfully, the way we've thought
about medicine for the last hundred years.

00:14:52.358 --> 00:14:56.774
But we need new models
to think about medicine in the future.

00:14:56.798 --> 00:14:58.278
That's what's at stake.

00:14:59.438 --> 00:15:02.774
You know, there's
a popular trope out there

00:15:02.798 --> 00:15:06.774
that the reason we haven't had
the transformative impact

00:15:06.798 --> 00:15:08.774
on the treatment of illness

00:15:08.798 --> 00:15:11.654
is because we don't have
powerful-enough drugs,

00:15:11.678 --> 00:15:13.038
and that's partly true.

00:15:14.078 --> 00:15:15.574
But perhaps the real reason is

00:15:15.598 --> 00:15:18.798
that we don't have powerful-enough
ways of thinking about medicines.

00:15:20.518 --> 00:15:22.934
It's certainly true that

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:26.734
it would be lovely to have new medicines.

00:15:26.758 --> 00:15:31.414
But perhaps what's really at stake
are three more intangible M's:

00:15:31.438 --> 00:15:35.254
mechanisms, models, metaphors.

00:15:35.278 --> 00:15:36.614
Thank you.

00:15:36.638 --> 00:15:43.478
(Applause)

00:15:45.558 --> 00:15:48.974
Chris Anderson:
I really like this metaphor.

00:15:48.998 --> 00:15:50.534
How does it link in?

00:15:50.558 --> 00:15:53.694
There's a lot of talk in technologyland

00:15:53.718 --> 00:15:55.854
about the personalization of medicine,

00:15:55.878 --> 00:15:59.294
that we have all this data
and that medical treatments of the future

00:15:59.318 --> 00:16:03.814
will be for you specifically,
your genome, your current context.

00:16:03.838 --> 00:16:07.774
Does that apply to this model
you've got here?

00:16:07.798 --> 00:16:10.414
Siddhartha Mukherjee:
It's a very interesting question.

00:16:10.438 --> 00:16:12.654
We've thought about
personalization of medicine

00:16:12.678 --> 00:16:14.214
very much in terms of genomics.

00:16:14.238 --> 00:16:16.814
That's because the gene
is such a dominant metaphor,

00:16:16.838 --> 00:16:19.814
again, to use that same word,
in medicine today,

00:16:19.838 --> 00:16:23.574
that we think the genome will drive
the personalization of medicine.

00:16:23.598 --> 00:16:26.694
But of course the genome
is just the bottom

00:16:26.718 --> 00:16:30.534
of a long chain of being, as it were.

00:16:30.558 --> 00:16:34.374
That chain of being, really the first
organized unit of that, is the cell.

00:16:34.398 --> 00:16:37.374
So, if we are really going to deliver
in medicine in this way,

00:16:37.398 --> 00:16:40.214
we have to think of personalizing
cellular therapies,

00:16:40.238 --> 00:16:43.414
and then personalizing
organ or organismal therapies,

00:16:43.438 --> 00:16:47.254
and ultimately personalizing
immersion therapies for the environment.

00:16:47.278 --> 00:16:50.374
So I think at every stage, you know --

00:16:50.398 --> 00:16:52.814
there's that metaphor,
there's turtles all the way.

00:16:52.838 --> 00:16:55.219
Well, in this, there's
personalization all the way.

00:16:55.243 --> 00:16:58.134
CA: So when you say
medicine could be a cell

00:16:58.158 --> 00:16:59.974
and not a pill,

00:16:59.998 --> 00:17:02.254
you're talking about
potentially your own cells.

00:17:02.278 --> 00:17:04.654
SM: Absolutely.
CA: So converted to stem cells,

00:17:04.678 --> 00:17:09.214
perhaps tested against all kinds
of drugs or something, and prepared.

00:17:09.238 --> 00:17:11.774
SM: And there's no perhaps.
This is what we're doing.

00:17:11.798 --> 00:17:15.534
This is what's happening,
and in fact, we're slowly moving,

00:17:15.558 --> 00:17:19.373
not away from genomics,
but incorporating genomics

00:17:19.398 --> 00:17:24.133
into what we call multi-order,
semi-autonomous, self-regulating systems,

00:17:24.158 --> 00:17:26.774
like cells, like organs,
like environments.

00:17:26.787 --> 00:17:28.165
CA: Thank you so much.

00:17:28.185 --> 00:17:29.475
SM: Pleasure. Thanks.
